visa_info:
Once accepted into the Exchange Program, Georgia Tech’s Office of International Education (OIE) will email the student with a link to the DS-2019 Information e-form requesting the following documents:
• Copy of Passport (biographical page)
• Financial Documentation
Georgia Tech will then issue and mail the DS-2019 form according to the preference indicated in the nomination form. Student must then:
• Pay I-901 SEVIS fee at fmjfee.com
• Apply for a J-1 Visa
• Please visit travel.state.gov and j1visa.state.gov for visa application information.
Please note: Visas can take several weeks to process. Students should apply for the J-1 Visa as soon as possible.
When traveling to the United States, student’s passport must be valid at least 6 months into the future.
accommodations_info:
Georgia Tech and the surrounding Atlanta neighbourhoods offer a wide variety of housing options to suit most preferences. Many Exchange students want a more standard US college experience and therefore choose to live on-campus. Others prefer a bit more freedom and ease of living among Atlantans rather than students 24/7. Whichever you think is best for you, please keep the following information in mind as you prepare to study at Georgia Tech.
On-Campus: Exchange students must be formally admitted to Georgia Tech before you can apply to live on campus. This means completing all of the requirements (all 3 steps) of the application process. If you think you want to live on campus, please complete your application as early as possible. On-campus housing does fill up, and we want every student who wants to live on campus to have that opportunity. Georgia Tech cannot guarantee on-campus housing to all applicants.
Off-Campus: Please click here for a few tips on finding off-campus housing.
cost_of_living: Please refer to this webpage - https://oie.gatech.edu/accordion-exchange-student-application - and scroll down to the Costs associated with GT Exchange tab for more information on the cost of an exchange at GA Tech.

university_name: The Chinese University of Hong Kong
module_restrictions: All English-taught courses at CUHK are open to exchange students, with some exceptions.
visa_info: All non-local students admitted as exchange or study abroad students at The Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK) must apply for a student visa at the Hong Kong Immigration Department through the Office of Academic Links (OAL), the local sponsor, before coming to Hong Kong.
accommodations_info: Undergraduate exchange students are guaranteed in on-campus housing and are assigned to double or triple-occupancy rooms. Living with local students will ease the transition to a new environment and promote Chinese culture immersion. No separate application for on-campus housing is required.
cost_of_living: The estimated monthly living expenses breakdown for the Chinese University of Hong Kong includes accommodation (HK$2,100 - HK$2,235), food (HK$4,500 - HK$5,000), transport (HK$700), and others (HK$1,000 - HK$2,000), resulting in a monthly estimate of HK$8,300 - HK$9,935.

module_restrictions: Both undergraduates and postgraduate Business and Law modules at TalTech are not offered to NUS students. Most of the courses which are conducted in English are Master level courses. As an exchange student, you can choose both Bachelor and Master level courses, but please take note that there are stricter pre-requisites for Master level courses. TalTech no longer offers the master programme on Work and Organizational Psychology. TalTech's strengths are in Computer Science and therefore these modules could be oversubscribed and not available.
visa_info: If you are staying in Estonia for more than three months, the Estonian authority requires you to apply for a Long-stay (D) visa. It is recommended that you secure necessary visa before leaving for Estonia. Please note that the application procedure for the travel documents for students outside EU may take up to 2 months.
accommodations_info: For exchange students, accommodation is offered in the Academic Hostels situated in the university campus and in the city centre. The campus reception is open 24/7, you can arrive any time. Accommodation is not guaranteed and limited places are available to students who apply and pay the deposit before the stipulated deadline. It is easier to get university accommodation in the Spring semester or semester 2. Students who failed to secure university accommodation have to find private accommodation on their own.
cost_of_living: The estimated monthly living expenses can be found at https://www.ttu.ee/studying/exchange-studies/exchange-studies-incomingoutgoing/before-studies/cost-of-living/

module_restrictions: Cross-faculty course booking is allowed, however students should attend most of their courses in their major and minor(s). Restrictions also apply to specific departments.
visa_info: Nominated students from countries with visa obligation will receive a form for immigration and further information directly from the International Relations Office of the University of Zurich.
accommodations_info: The University of Zurich does not own student dormitories. However, the International Relations Office has access to a limited number of rooms for exchange students from partner universities, which are administered by the Housing Office of the University of Zurich and ETH.
cost_of_living: The estimated monthly living expenses include accommodation (CHF 620 - 790), food (CHF 450), transport (CHF 100), insurance (CHF 100), and other expenses such as entertainment and clothes (CHF 600). The total monthly estimate is approximately CHF 1,870 - 2,040.

faculties_accepted: School of Social Sciences (excluding School of Law)
module_restrictions:
All post-graduate modules with code 6xxx are NOT available to undergraduate students on exchange.
Modules taught at Sheffield’s International Faculty – City College based in Thessaloniki Greece are NOT open to exchange students.
visa_info:
UK Visa and Immigration updates their immigration policy regularly. It is
the student’s responsibility to check on the requirements via their website
before they leave for the exchange.
https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/uk-visas-and-immigration
For latest information on border control please see:
https://www.gov.uk/uk-border-control

Standard Visitor Visa for Semester Exchange
If you are a Singapore citizen or a citizen of another country on the UK non-
visa nationals list, and if your course of studies is less than 6 months, you will
request entry to the UK as a Standard Visitor when you arrive.
Singapore citizens do not normally need to meet with a Border Force agent,
and will be able to enter the UK through E-gates. The E-gates will
automatically grant you permission to stay in the UK for up to 6 months.
You will not receive a stamp on your passport thus it is important that you
retain evidence of when you entered the UK. Hence, please keep your
boarding pass or evidence of your flight itinerary.
Please refer here for more details on the Standard Visitor Visa.
Student Visa for Full-Year Exchange
You need a Student Visa for a full-year exchange in Sheffield.
For more details on visa application, read the information available here.
All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after
they received the official offer letter/email from their host university. Some
visa application processes can take up to 2 months to process. Your exchange
at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the
host country.
Sheffield’s information on Visa and Immigration can be found here:
https://www.sheffield.ac.uk/ssid/immigration/index
Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the
immigration of the host country.
accommodations_info:
For approved December Finish applicants:
Sheffield’s Accommodation and Commercial Services liaise with Global
Opportunities and Exchanges to offer short term contracts (i.e. less than a
semester) to December Finish students.
Normally “December Finish” students are housed together within University
accommodation and full details of property and rent will be advised following
application.
If Accommodation and Commercial Services cannot offer a short-term
contract, students need to apply for and accept a semester contract and pay
for the extra weeks. This cannot be waived. Alternatively, students can try
and find accommodation in the private sector but you must let Sheffield
know if you will do this.
For non-December Finish students and students joining Sheffield in
semester 2:
A room at Sheffield’s university accommodation is guaranteed for the full
duration of semester 2. However, the preferred room type cannot be
guaranteed.
Once students are accepted, they will be directed to the Accommodation
Office. More information about accommodation can be found at:
https://www.sheffield.ac.uk/accommodation

Private Accommodation
December Finish applicants have to source for private accommodation on
their own if they do not wish to pay for the extra weeks as stated in the
university accommodation contract.
cost_of_living: The University of Sheffield provides an estimated cost of living which can be found at https://www.sheffield.ac.uk/international/enquiry/money/costs. Scholarships are available for eligible students, more information can be found at https://www.sheffield.ac.uk/globalopps/inbound/fees-funding/scholarships.

module_restrictions: There is no restriction in courses or programmes for exchange students. However, students must keep in mind that the language of instruction in some departments is mainly in Turkish. Students need the approval of the instructor if they wish to take courses that have prerequisite requirements and courses from graduate programs. Course information: https://stars.bilkent.edu.tr/homepage/academic_units.php. Previous semester course offerings are for reference only and are subject to changes. Courses will only be finalized by the offering departments upon arrival at Bilkent.
visa_info: Students coming from the countries, which are exempted from the visa requirement to Turkey, do not have to apply to the Turkish Embassy/Consulates for any type of visa and may directly come to Turkey with their passports. Residence permit application will be made during the Orientation Program. Students who need 'student visa' to enter Turkey are supposed to apply for the student visa at the Turkish Consulate as soon as they receive their acceptance letter. Students are advised to have adequate time for the visa to be processed prior to the departure.
accommodations_info: Bilkent University offers FREE on-campus housing for all exchange students. The offer is valid for double rooms and allocations are on a first-come-first-served basis. In the acceptance packages, students will receive their Bilkent ID number and a STARS Password which they have to use for their online application to the dormitories. Accommodation application periods: (Sem 1): 15 May to 14 July 2017, (Sem 2): 15 December 2017 to 14 January 2018.
cost_of_living: More information about estimated semester living expenses can be found here: http://www.bilkent.edu.tr/bilkent/academic/exchange/cost.html. Please note that direct application by students will not be accepted by the International Relations Office (IRO). For SEP, eligible students who have received the NASA Exchange Award will be invited to apply for YTP-Market Immersion funding. More information can be found here: http://www.nus.edu.sg/iro/fa/sch/out/ytp.html.

university_name: The University of Texas at Austin
module_restrictions: Some programs at UT are either highly selective due to high student demand, require specific application requirements, or are completely unavailable to exchange students. Programmes not open to the general exchange can be found here and on the Application page. Courses designated “restricted” require students to obtain permission to take those classes from the department advisor or course instructor during registration week.
visa_info: All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they receive the official offer letter/email from their host university. Some visa application processes can take up to 2 months to process. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country. For more information, please refer to the following webpage: https://world.utexas.edu/isss/visa
accommodations_info: On-campus housing is not guaranteed at UT Austin. For more information on housing options and estimated costs, please refer to the following page: https://world.utexas.edu/isss/life/housing
cost_of_living: The estimated monthly living expenses at The University of Texas at Austin can be found at http://www.collegecalc.org/colleges/texas/the-university-of-texas-at-austin/. Tuition is waived for exchange students. Information correct as of July 2021. Please refer to the UT Austin links for the latest information.

faculties_accepted: The College of Science and Engineering
module_restrictions: Visiting students are unable to take courses in the areas of Medicine, Vet Medicine, and Dentistry. They also cannot take Level 5 courses. Postgraduate modules are not open to undergraduate exchange students.
visa_info: UK Visa and Immigration updates their immigration policy regularly. It is the student’s responsibility to check on the requirements via their website before they leave for the exchange. Singapore citizens or citizens of another country on the UK non-visa nationals list, and if the course of studies is less than 6 months, can request entry to the UK as a Standard Visitor when they arrive.
accommodations_info: All students on the Exchange programme are guaranteed university accommodation but are not guaranteed preferred choice of accommodation. Once accepted onto the programme, students will be emailed details on how to apply for accommodation. Rooms are allocated on a first-come, first-served basis.
cost_of_living: The estimated cost of living per month can be found at https://www.gla.ac.uk/study/studentlife/costofliving/#costpermonth-examples.

faculties_accepted: Center for Education in Liberal Arts and Sciences
module_restrictions: Please refer to http://www.osaka-u.ac.jp/en/international/inbound/exchange_program for module restrictions and prerequisites.
visa_info:
Upon acceptance, Osaka U will apply for a Certificate of Eligibility on your behalf with the Japanese Ministry of Justice, and send it to you when issued. The certificate is required for you to apply for a study visa.

Exchange students must obtain a “College Student” visa for the duration of their study in Japan.  Please visit the Japan Embassy website for the required supporting documents for your visa application.

All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university. This is to ensure that you can obtain your visa in time before the start of your exchange term. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country.

For more information on visa applications, please refer to https://iss-intl.osaka-u.ac.jp/supportoffice/eng/visa/

http://www.mofa.go.jp/j_info/visit/visa/index.html
accommodations_info:
Exchange students will be housed in the university housing. Due to lack of housing in Osaka, students may not be placed in the dormitory of their choice. 

Dormitory fees are about JP¥20,000 – JP¥40,000 per month, including electricity, gas, and water fees, come to about. Exchange student dormitories at Osaka University contain no dining facilities.

Applications for housing will be accepted through the exchange program application webpage simultaneously with the confirmation of intent to enter the university after acceptance into the exchange program.

For more information about accommodation, please refer to https://iss-intl.osaka-u.ac.jp/supportoffice/eng/housing/
cost_of_living:
The estimated monthly living expenses include:

- Accommodation: JP¥16,000 - JP¥40,000
- Food: ~ JP¥30,000
- Transport: JP¥5,000 - JP¥15,000
- Insurance: JP¥2,000 - JP¥3,000
- General school related expenses (supplies, books, etc.): JP¥6,000
- Others (Entertainment, clothes): ~ JP¥30,000

The monthly estimate for living expenses ranges from JP¥89,000 - JP¥124,000.

For more student exchange information, please refer to https://www.osaka-u.ac.jp/sp/whyou/admission/fees/

faculties_accepted: Fine arts, applied and performing arts
module_restrictions: No specific module restrictions mentioned.
visa_info: If you are a citizen of a non EU/EEA country and are planning to stay for longer than three months, you need a residence permit before entering Sweden. You apply for a residence permit online or at the Swedish embassy or consulate in your home country. The process of getting your residence permit may take up to 12 weeks, so be sure to apply as soon as you receive your letter of acceptance. It is important that you have your residence permit card with you when entering Sweden. To obtain a residence permit you must have a valid passport, be admitted to full-time studies, be able to support yourself financially, and have a comprehensive health insurance if you are admitted to studies for less than one year.
accommodations_info: Applying for our services. Students should apply for housing after they have submitted their online application. Students will receive a unique housing application code once submitted their online application. Deadline for housing application is the same as the online application. No late applications can be accepted. Apply as soon as possible, since there is a great demand for housing. You do not have to be academically accepted before you apply online for non-academic services. The rooms and flats that we rent out are provided by SGS Studentbostäder, the local student housing company. Reservations and payment are managed by the university or by the local student housing company. Accommodation for exchange students is provided by the local student housing company, SGS Studentbostäder. All rooms come with a private bathroom and basic furniture, such as a desk, a bookshelf, a bed, chairs and lamps. Pillows, sheets, towels, kitchen utensils, light bulbs etc. are not provided. The rent includes electricity, water, heating, internet access (you will have to bring your own computer and network cable) and laundry facilities.
cost_of_living: Estimated Monthly Living Expenses: Accommodation: SEK4,000 – SEK7,000, Food: SEK3,000 – SEK4,000, Transport: SEK580, Telephone/Internet: SEK300, Others (Entertainment, clothes): SEK2,000. Monthly Estimate: SEK10,300 – SEK14,000.

module_restrictions: If you are considering modules at 3000 level or above, you should have significant background knowledge of the subject (usually two years of study at university).
Postgraduate modules are not open to undergraduate exchange students.
visa_info:
UK Visa and Immigration updates their immigration policy regularly. It is the student’s responsibility to check on the requirements via their website before they leave for the exchange. [Link](https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/uk-visas-and-immigration)

For latest information on border control please see: [Link](https://www.gov.uk/uk-border-control)

Standard Visitor Visa for Semester Exchange
If you are a Singapore citizen or a citizen of another country on the UK non-visa nationals list, and if your course of studies is less than 6 months, you will request entry to the UK as a Standard Visitor when you arrive.

Singapore citizens do not normally need to meet with a Border Force agent, and will be able to enter the UK through E-gates. The E-gates will automatically grant you permission to stay in the UK for up to 6 months.

You will not receive a stamp on your passport thus it is important that you retain evidence of when you entered the UK. Hence, please keep your boarding pass or evidence of your flight itinerary.

Please refer [here](https://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/study/support/international-students/moving-to-uk/visas/) for more details on the Standard Visitor Visa.

Student Visa for Full-Year Exchange
You need a Student Visa for a full-year exchange in St Andrews.

For more details on visa application, read the information available [here](https://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/study/support/international-students/moving-to-uk/visas/).

All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university. Some visa application processes can take up to 2 months to process. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country.

St Andrew’s information on Visa and Immigration can be found [here](https://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/study/support/international-students/moving-to-uk/visas/). Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country.
accommodations_info:
University Accommodation

Exchange students who are undergraduates are guaranteed university housing provided you return the housing form by the deadlines. However, preference of room is not guaranteed. For more information, please refer to [this link](https://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/study-abroad/at-st-andrews/applying/accommodation/)
cost_of_living: Information on cost of living can be found at [this link](https://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/students/money/internationalstudents/ugcoa/)

module_restrictions: Due to high demand, the Economics and Finance Department will enroll students in only one class. There is also a limited range of classes in the Communications, Computer Science, and Marketing departments.
visa_info: All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they receive the official offer letter/email from their host university. Some visa application processes can take up to 2 months to process. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country.
accommodations_info: The availability of on-campus accommodations for exchange students is extremely limited and rooms are assigned by lottery. Most exchange students live in off-campus accommodations such as shared houses or apartments with other BC and international students. The BC Off-Campus Housing Services office provides assistance to exchange students in locating housing both before and after arrival in Boston.
cost_of_living:
The estimated monthly living expenses prepared by BC are as follows:
- On-Campus Housing: USD $4,890 - $6,530 per semester
- Meal Plan: USD $2,911 per semester for meal plan (required by certain dorms)
- BC Mandatory Medical Insurance: USD $1,500 fall semester; $3,620 full year (cannot be waived)
- University Fees: USD $1,211 per year
- Books & Personal expenses: USD $2,650 per semester (does not include entertainment or travel

For more information, please refer to the following webpage: [https://www.bc.edu/bc-web/offices/student-services/billing-student-accounts/tuition-fees.html](https://www.bc.edu/bc-web/offices/student-services/billing-student-accounts/tuition-fees.html)

module_restrictions: Course restrictions may be limited as prerequisites may be required. Maximum of two Business courses may be taken per semester. CMU’s School of Design, within their College of Fine Arts, is unable to welcome students at this time due to special constraints. This may be possible in the future.
visa_info: All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they receive the official offer letter/email from their host university. Some visa application processes can take up to 2 months to process. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country. Critical immigration procedures are discussed in the cover letter which accompanied your Certificate of Eligibility. Read this information very carefully to know the correct procedures for your particular situation. When you are traveling to the US, make sure you carry your original documents (passport, DS-2019, evidence of admission and financial resources) with you in your carry-on luggage. For more information, please refer here: https://www.cmu.edu/oie/foreign-students/maintain-legal-status/index.html
accommodations_info: The Housing and Dining Services offers traditional single-gender residence halls, coeducational residence halls, suites, apartments, houses, fraternity and sorority houses and special interest housing. Please note that room rates differ for each of these categories. University housing is available both on and off campus to all first-year students 17 years of age or older. First-year students under the age of 17 are asked to contact the Office of Housing Services. Transfer student housing is subject to availability and transfer students should contact the Office of Housing Services for more information. Housing facilities, located on the campus proper, are conveniently close to the academic buildings. The Oakland Community Apartments are located within a 5-10 minute walking distance to campus. The Oakland Community Apartments are serviced by the University's shuttle service on a regular basis.
cost_of_living:
CMU has prepared the following estimated budget for exchange students:

Living expenses: USD $7,486
Books, Supplies, Fees, Misc: USD $1,664
CMU Health Insurance: USD $2,573
TOTAL: $11,723
Please refer to the following link for more information on the cost of living at CMU. Please note NUS students going to CMU on SEP will not pay tuition fees to CMU: https://www.cmu.edu/sfs/tuition/undergraduate/index.html

university_name: Cornell University - College of Agriculture & Life Sciences (CALS)
module_restrictions: Cornell cannot guarantee enrollment in any course. Course availability cannot be guaranteed and course offerings are always subject to change. Some courses require prerequisites.
visa_info: All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they receive the official offer letter/email from their host university. Some visa application processes can take up to 2 months to process.
accommodations_info: In recent years, Cornell has experienced an increased demand for on-campus housing, and as a result, on-campus housing is not usually available for incoming exchange students. Exchange students should refer to the resources provided by Cornell for housing options, including cooperative housing and off-campus housing. Cornell also has an exchange housing program to assist students in finding suitable accommodations.
cost_of_living: The estimated monthly living expenses can be found on Cornell's financial aid website. Tuition fees are waived for exchange students.

faculties_accepted: College of Design and Engineering (CDE or FoE)
Yong Loo Lin School of Medicine (YLLSOM)
module_restrictions: Only students who are in Year 3 of their study when embarking for SEP can apply to go to TU Delft. It is important that you have the relevant academic background for the courses that you apply for. You must have taken modules at NUS within the specific subject field to be accepted to any of the faculties/departments at TU Delft.
visa_info: Information about immigration-related issues is available at: https://www.tudelft.nl/en/education/practical-matters/visa-residence-permit/ Additionally, you can contact the Dutch embassy in Singapore if you have a specific enquiry that the host university is unable to address.
accommodations_info: Information about student housing is available at: https://www.tudelft.nl/en/education/practical-matters/housing/
cost_of_living: The cost of living and estimated expenses in Delft, Netherlands can be found at: https://www.tudelft.nl/en/education/practical-matters/tuition-fee-finances/.

faculties_accepted: Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences (FASS)
College of Design and Engineering (CDE or FoE)
Yong Loo Lin School of Medicine (YLLSOM)
Yong Siew Toh Conservatory of Music (YSTCM)
visa_info: Exchange students must apply to New Zealand Immigration for a student visa and obtain the visa before entering New Zealand. Please note that it is NOT possible for exchange students to travel to New Zealand on a visitor's visa and apply for a student permit upon arrival in New Zealand, even if you are a citizen of a country with which New Zealand has a visa waiver agreement. It is imperative that all exchange students get their student visa BEFORE travelling to New Zealand, as you may be refused a student permit if you apply from within New Zealand. Students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university. This is to ensure that you can obtain your visa in time before the start of your exchange term. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country. For more information on visa applications, please refer to https://www.immigration.govt.nz/new-zealand-visas/options/study
accommodations_info: Exchange students are required to purchase a compulsory medical and travel insurance when studying in New Zealand. The University of Auckland’s preferred insurance policy for International students is Studentsafe-University. The estimated cost is NZ$350 per semester. The Studentsafe insurance fee will be charged to students account automatically upon enrolment. It is recommended that you purchase a comprehensive travel insurance for the full duration of your stay abroad, including your personal travel within/outside Australia. Please review the insurance coverages to ensure that they meet your needs. Students can purchase additional health and/or travel insurance from their preferred agent.
cost_of_living: The University of Auckland does not provide a specific breakdown of the cost of living in the PDF. However, students should be prepared for expenses such as accommodation, food, transportation, study materials, and personal expenses. The cost of living in Auckland is generally higher compared to other cities in New Zealand. According to various sources, the estimated monthly living expenses for a student in Auckland range from NZD 1,200 to NZD 2,000. This includes accommodation, groceries, transportation, and entertainment. It is important to budget and plan accordingly to ensure a comfortable stay during the exchange program.

faculties_accepted: Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences (FASS)
College of Design and Engineering (CDE or FoE)
Yong Loo Lin School of Medicine (YLLSOM)
module_restrictions: The courses offered at the School of Business and Economics and the Helmholtz Institute for Biomedical Engineering are not open to NUS students.
visa_info: EU citizens and citizens from Australia, Canada, Honduras, Iceland, Israel, Japan, Korea, Liechtenstein, Monaco, New Zealand, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland, and the United States do not need a visa to enter Germany. All other students must apply for a visa for study purposes via the German diplomatic representation in their home country. Health insurance is compulsory in Germany.
accommodations_info: As an exchange student from NUS, you can apply for so-called “quota rooms” in the student dorms. However, the number of exchange students and scholarship holders exceeds the number of reserved rooms, so there is no guarantee of allocation. Students who have a contract that ends in August or September are expected to pay for the rental until that time with no refunds.
cost_of_living:
The estimated monthly living expenses in Aachen are as follows:

- Accommodation: €250 - €440
- Insurance: €80
- Food: €350
- University fees: €42
- Others (Books, entertainment, etc.): €150

The monthly estimate ranges from €872 to €1,062. Students need to show proof of financial support of at least €735 per month to receive a residence permit.

module_restrictions: Postgraduate modules are not open to undergraduate exchange students. Modules from Warwick Business School and Warwick School of Law are also not available to NUS students with no matching major.
visa_info: UK Visa and Immigration updates their immigration policy regularly. It is the student’s responsibility to check on the requirements via their website before they leave for the exchange. Standard Visitor Visa for Semester Exchange: Singapore citizens or citizens of another country on the UK non-visa nationals list requesting entry for less than 6 months will enter as a Standard Visitor when they arrive. Student Visa for Full-Year Exchange: A student visa is required for a full-year exchange at Warwick.
accommodations_info: Warwick accommodation is subject to availability of rooms. Exchange students are encouraged to live on campus, but there are options available for off-campus housing.
cost_of_living: The University of Warwick provides an estimate of monthly living expenses. For detailed information, please visit their website: [https://warwick.ac.uk/study/international/admissions/finance/livingcosts].

university_name: Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST)
module_restrictions: Students are required to meet the pre-requisites for the courses that they applied for and take 50% of the courses from their major department at KAIST. Undergraduate students can apply for courses starting with course no. 1xx to 4xx. Master-level courses are not open to undergraduate students.
visa_info: Exchange students must apply for a D2 student visa before arrival in Korea. After you received the Certificate of Admission (CoA) and offer letter from your host university, you may proceed to the Korean Embassy to apply for the student visa, with the relevant supporting documents.
accommodations_info: KAIST will apply for on-campus accommodation for all exchange students based on their student exchange application. The assigned dormitories (Double or Triple occupancy) for exchange students are furnished with beds, closets, desks and chairs for each room. Share faculties include restrooms, showers, washing machines, clothes drier, and a lobby on each floor. For more information about accommodation, please refer to https://kds.kaist.ac.kr/eng/index.do
cost_of_living:
Estimated Monthly Living Expenses:

- Accommodation: ₩250,000
- Food: ₩300,000
- Transport: ₩100,000
- Academic Expenses: ₩50,000
- Others (Entertainment, clothes): ₩250,000

Monthly Estimate: ₩950,000

module_restrictions: All courses listed on http://www.uu.se/en/admissions/exchange/course/ are open to exchange students and will be taught in English, provided that they fulfil the prerequisites and have certain restrictions as mentioned on the website.
visa_info: All non-EU citizens need to apply for a residence permit to stay longer than 90 days in Sweden. Students must have been admitted as an exchange or visiting student at Uppsala University and must prove sufficient funds for their entire stay duration. Residence permit application can only be made at a Swedish Embassy or Consulate in the home country or country of residence.
accommodations_info: Housing is not guaranteed but is prioritized for exchange students who apply within specific deadlines. Students should apply for housing as soon as the housing application period opens. Students are living in rooms and apartments as tenants and are responsible for their accommodation. Male and female students live on the same corridors. More information on accommodation can be found at http://www.uu.se/en/admissions/exchange/housing-and-financing/ and http://www.housingoffice.se/
cost_of_living: The estimated monthly living expenses in Uppsala are as follows: Accommodation: SEK 5,000, Food: SEK 2,100, Transport: SEK 300, Telephone/Internet: SEK 200, Others (Entertainment, clothes): SEK 900, totaling to a monthly estimate of SEK 8,500.

module_restrictions: Please search for English taught courses carefully. Only for NUS students who have completed at least 2 years of studies at NUS before the exchange starts at TUD. Undergraduate exchange students with sufficient language proficiency and who meet the pre-requisites for master-level courses will be considered for TUD’s master courses. Courses belonging to Anglistics and English Literature are not open for exchange students.
visa_info: EU citizens and citizens from the following countries do not need a visa to enter Germany: Australia, Canada, Honduras, Iceland, Israel, Japan, Korea, Liechtenstein, Monaco, New Zealand, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland and the United States. However, after entering Germany, you will have to apply for a residence permit at the local 'Auslaenderbehörde' (Immigration Office) if you are staying for more than three months. Students from all other countries must apply for a visa for study purposes via the German diplomatic representation in their home country. You must not under any circumstances travel to Germany on a tourist visa.
accommodations_info: Accommodation is available in dormitories of Studierendenwerk Darmstadt. NUS students are guaranteed accommodation. The allocation of accommodation usually takes place approx. 1 – 1.5 months prior to the Kick-Off Meeting. In charge of room allocation is the 'Welcome and Housing Department'. Students who have a contract that ends in August or September are expected to pay for the rental until August or September. There will be no refund of the rental if you leave the student accommodation earlier. In case rooms in dormitories are not available, the TUD department will assist the students in finding accommodation by sending them a detailed guidebook via e-mail. For more information, please refer to http://www.tu-darmstadt.de/exchange-housing.
cost_of_living:
The estimated monthly living expenses in Darmstadt are as follows:

- Accommodation: €350 - €500
- Food: €300
- Transport: Included in semester contribution
- Compulsory Health Insurance: €90
- Others (Entertainment, clothes): €100

Monthly Estimate: €840 - €990

All enrolled students at TUD are required to pay a semester contribution of approx. €218 per semester that includes a ticket for public transportation within the wider area of Rhein-Main Region. In order to receive a residence permit, you need to present to the Ausländerbehörde (local foreigner’s registration office) a statement of financial support proving that you have at least €735 to live on for each month of your stay. This can either be a bank statement, a notarized parental letter, or a scholarship certificate.

module_restrictions: Exchange students are rarely, if ever, allowed to enroll in courses from UW-Madison professional schools (Medicine, Veterinary Medicine, Pharmacy, Nursing, Law, Education, etc). Some courses (for example, Economics) are open to exchange students, but are very popular and fill quickly during enrollment time. Within any single department, there may be some courses which are not open to exchange students, or fill entirely with UW-Madison degree-seeking students. Flexibility is key to successful enrollment!
visa_info: If you are interested in taking classes at UW-Madison, your visa status needs to allow you to study at this institution. With few exceptions—English as a Second Language (ESL) and formal exchange students—the Adult and Student Services Center is not authorized to issue the I-20 or DS-2019 for a student visa. Students who hold F-1 or J-1 student visas are not eligible to "transfer" this status to UW-Madison while holding a student visa issued from another school, except for the summer term.
accommodations_info: On-campus housing is through the Division of University Housing. The University residence halls (also known as dormitories) are a short walk or short ride on the campus circular bus route (Route 80) to class. The University residence halls are single, double, or triple occupancy rooms without kitchens and with shared bathrooms. All University residence hall students have access to University residence hall dining rooms. Students can purchase food à la carte at a variety of University Housing dining locations. Off-campus housing is owned and operated by private individuals or companies and therefore, our office in unable to make any commitment or advance arrangements for off-campus housing. Most off-campus housing opportunities require a yearlong lease.
cost_of_living: The estimated monthly living expenses can be found at the following link: https://financialaid.wisc.edu/cost-of-attendance/ (Please note tuition fees are waived due to exchange status).

module_restrictions: Some courses with capacity limit do not accept exchange students. For prerequisite required courses, students must have taken courses considered equivalent to the prerequisite. Exchange students are normally allowed to take courses at undergraduate level only (course level: B1-B4) unless approved otherwise.
visa_info: Details and procedures can be found at http://www.immd.gov.hk and http://www.cityu.edu.hk/geo. Students are encouraged to apply for student visa to Hong Kong via CityU. CityU may act as the local sponsor of exchange students who are accepted for admission and meet Hong Kong visa application requirements. Completed application form and other necessary documents should be sent to the Global Services Office, Rm 3210, 3/F, Cheng Yick-chi Building, City University of Hong Kong, Tat Chee Avenue, Kowloon, Hong Kong SAR at least 6-8 weeks before the semester starts. An Administrative Fee for Student Visa/Entry Permit Application at HK$600 will be charged. The fee is non-refundable and non-transferable. As the student visa/entry permit application processing may take 8 weeks or even longer, students should file their application by the following deadline: Semester A (September Intake): 1st June, Semester B (January Intake): 1st November *Students are encouraged to file their student visa/entry permit application first even if they have not yet received the letter of acceptance.
accommodations_info: Exchange students may apply for accommodation at Student Residence but it is NOT guaranteed due to limited spaces. Allocation of accommodation will be made by a random ballot. Students should file their accommodation application before the deadline. Exchange students may choose to stay in commercially operated accommodation recommended by CityU, or rent your own flat on the market. Students will be invited to join a Facebook group with guidance on searching off-campus housing in Hong Kong and to find suitable flatmates to share a flat in the city. The rental for off-campus accommodations varies, depending on the size, location, age of the building, etc.
cost_of_living:

- Off-campus Accommodation: HK$5,625 – HK$6,875
- Food: HK$3,000
- Transport: HK$300
- Others (Entertainment, clothes, books, electricity etc): HK$1,200
Monthly Estimate: HK$10,125 – HK$11,375

university_name: Pohang University of Science and Technology (POSTECH)
module_restrictions: Students are required to meet the pre-requisites for the courses that they applied.
visa_info: Exchange students must apply for a D2 student visa before arrival in Korea. After you received the Certificate of Admission (CoA) and offer letter from your host university, you may proceed to the Korean Embassy to apply for the student visa, with the relevant supporting documents.
accommodations_info: International exchange students will be housed at the Dormitory for International Cultural Exchange (DICE) on twin sharing basis. All rooms are equipped with free internet, LAN connections and lounges with cable TV are available on every floor. Admitted students are automatically arranged on-campus housing.
cost_of_living:

- Academic Expenses: ₩50,000

module_restrictions: Physical education courses, foreign language courses, and courses in School of Medicine are not open to exchange students. KIP students who wish to take Japanese language courses will go through a self-graded test and will be placed in the level determined by his/her score for the test. In addition, students who wish to take advanced subjects must take the JLP placement test to be placed into advanced or higher study levels. All JLP students are required to take the Japanese language program placement test at the beginning of each semester.
visa_info: Upon acceptance, Keio will apply for a Certificate of Eligibility on your behalf with the Japanese Ministry of Justice, and send it to you when issued. The certificate is required for you to apply for a study visa. Exchange students must obtain a 'College Student' visa for the duration of their study in Japan. Please visit the Japan Embassy website for the required supporting documents for your visa application. All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university. This is to ensure that you can obtain your visa in time before the start of your exchange term. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country.
accommodations_info: Keio housing (accommodations subsidized by Keio) is GUARANTEED for exchange students if they apply for housing on time. The rent charged to students varies from ¥55,000 to ¥79,100. Students will also be charged a one-time, additional maintenance fee of ¥20,000 for their first month’s rent. Deposits and key money are not required. Housing information and application form will be sent to students together with the acceptance letter. Waseda will provide students with a list of recommended off-campus accommodations in the event that the university dormitories are full.

module_restrictions: Modules from the Birmingham Business School, Law School, College of Medical and Dental Sciences are not open to NUS students.
visa_info: UK Visa and Immigration updates their immigration policy regularly. It is the student’s responsibility to check on the requirements via their website before they leave for the exchange. Standard Visitor Visa for Semester Exchange: If you are a Singapore citizen or a citizen of another country on the UK non-visa nationals list, and if your course of studies is less than 6 months, you will request entry to the UK as a Standard Visitor when you arrive. Singapore citizens do not normally need to meet with a Border Force agent, and will be able to enter the UK through E-gates. Student Visa for Full-Year Exchange: You need a Student Visa for a full-year exchange in Birmingham.
accommodations_info: University Accommodation: Birmingham guarantees accommodation for international exchange students. Students who need university accommodation should apply before the deadline. Private Accommodation: Alternatively, students may decide to rent private accommodation. Housing Services at Birmingham offers a list of approved landlords for students who wish to rent privately. They also run a House Hunting Event at the start of each year.
cost_of_living: Estimated Living Expenses: Details can be found at http://www.birmingham.ac.uk/International/study-abroad/study-abroad-incoming/preparing/finance.aspx

module_restrictions: The admission requirements (prerequisites) for each course can be found on the website of the relevant department. Many courses require at least 1 year of full-time studies within the subject area. Faculty of Law requires 2 years of prior studies in the subject. School of Architecture requires 3 years of prior studies in the subject. Portfolio required to apply. Courses at the School of Industrial Design at Lund University are only open to students enrolled at an Industrial Design program at their home university. Portfolio required to apply. It is recommended that the student’s level of English language proficiency is equivalent to IELTS 6.5/ TOEFL 90. The Swedish language requirement for exchange students wishing to study Swedish-taught courses is “Svenska 3” or equivalent. There is a limited availability of courses at the Lund University School of Economics and Management (LUSEM). Students applying through a university-wide agreement can at most be accepted to 15 credits at LUSEM per semester. The Faculty of Performing Arts, the Malmö Art Academy and the Faculty of Medicine mainly admit students within specific faculty/department agreements. Courses in Journalism are not available. Note: Not all courses in English are open to exchange students. Lund University allows exchange students to read a maximum of 30 credits + a 3 credits introductory course in Swedish (SUSA) per semester. As courses may vary in their number of credits, if a student takes 15 credits courses, he/she can only take two courses (+SUSA); if a student takes 7.5 credits courses, he/she can take four courses (+SUSA). Lund University will not allow students to overload. Students should make sure they fulfill the prerequisites and that they list several reserve alternatives to better their chances in securing 30 credits. The courses offered at the Faculty of Law in Lund University are all at Master level (advanced level); students must have completed a minimum of 2.5 years of previous law studies to be considered for Master level courses. Please note that not all courses given in English are open to exchange students.
visa_info: Students from countries outside the EU/EEA need to have a residence permit to study in Sweden. Exchange students coming to Sweden from a non-EU/EEA country may need a residence permit or visa to enter Sweden, depending on their citizenship. Students are advised to apply for a residence permit or visa at the Swedish Embassy or Consulate in their home country after receiving a letter of acceptance for exchange studies. All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they receive the official offer letter/email from their host university. Visa application process could take up to 3 months to process. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country.
accommodations_info: There are several different housing providers, LU Accommodation is one of them. An active search approach is encouraged since there is a shortage of housing at the beginning of each semester. It is recommended to apply for accommodation through several different agencies. Lund University provides information on accommodation options and applications through LU Accommodation. Students can also consider private accommodation options recommended by Lund University such as BoPoolen, AF Bostader, and accommodation at the student nations. Application periods for university accommodation are from 1-25 April for the autumn semester and 1-25 October for the spring semester. It is strongly recommended that students apply as soon as the application period opens.
cost_of_living:
The estimated monthly living expenses in Lund are as follows:

Breakdown of Costs:
- Accommodation: SEK3,200 – SEK4,800
- Food: SEK2,300
- Transport: SEK500
- Telephone/Internet: SEK400
- Others (Entertainment, clothes): SEK1,700

The monthly estimate ranges from SEK8,100 to SEK9,700. Students are required to have funds of at least SEK 8,514 per month of study to obtain a residence permit. Please note that students can find more detailed information on living costs on Lund University's website.

module_restrictions: Students are reminded to review the online course list carefully as it contains important information which is often ignored. Please read so that you will save time, effort and have less stress in your application process.
visa_info: All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university. Some visa application process could take up to 2 months to process. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country. A citizen of a non-EU country has to obtain the visa from the consulate of Poland in his/her country of residence to support their stay of more than 90 days in Poland. For details please contact the Polish Consulate in your country. All students should legalize their stay exceeding 3 months by obtaining temporary residence permit after their arrival to Poland with the help from WUT.
accommodations_info: WUT dormitories are located outside the campus but not very far. WUT offers around 5200 places in 12 dormitories in Warsaw. Most rooms are usually double or triple sharing. University accommodation is not guaranteed. Accommodation process is run by a special section of Students Union - Accommodation Commission (Komisja Kwaterunkowa). Whole process is run via online system called SEKS2. Candidates will be able to apply for dormitory. They will have to submit their applications through Online Accommodation System. Detailed information will be sent directly to candidates. The dormitory application procedure is fully arranged and run by Student’s Union Accommodation Committee. Please take note that there are separate intakes for different exchange students.

module_restrictions: Exchange students should take courses in the field for which the exchange was established. However, they can choose one or two courses from other schools/faculties if places are available. Business modules are meant for Business major students from NUS Business School. Students do not need to sign up for most classes beforehand, but can choose their courses upon arrival (except German language and culture courses offered by the International Office).
visa_info: EU citizens and citizens from the following countries do not need a visa to enter Germany: Australia, Canada, Honduras, Iceland, Israel, Japan, Korea, Liechtenstein, Monaco, New Zealand, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland and the United States. However, after entering Germany, you will have to apply for a residence permit at the local 'Auslaenderbehörde' (Immigration Office) if you are staying for more than three months. Students from all other countries must apply for a visa for study purposes via the German diplomatic representation in their home country. You must not under any circumstances travel to Germany on a tourist visa. All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they receive the official offer letter/email from their host university.
accommodations_info: Students can apply for student residences or look for a room on the private market. For exchange students from overseas, there are very limited number of places in Mannheim’s off-campus student residences: single bedrooms in student residences for €280 - €390, apartments €340 - €390. Rooms on the private market start at €280. There are furnished rooms (shared kitchen and bathroom) in several residences in different areas of Mannheim. After being accepted by the University of Mannheim, the student will receive the link and personal password for our online portal myUniMA, along with detailed information on the private housing market. Please note that the housing situation in Mannheim is a lot more relaxed in the spring semester. Thus, if students have the option between fall and spring, we recommend students to come during the spring semester.

Your 'host' department during your exchange will be the academic
department that offers the academic programme you are admitted to. 50%
(or more) of your enrolled subjects must come from the host department.
Being attached to a host department will give you priority in registering for
subjects within that department. The other 50% (or less) workload can be
subjects offered by other departments.  
All registrations are subject to the approval of the respective departments.  
For more information, please refer to  
https://www.polyu.edu.hk/geo/exchange-and-study-abroad/incoming-
students/incoming-exchange/ > Programme Information > 3. Choose your
Host Department
visa_info:
Global Engagement Office (GEO) will act as your visa sponsor and send all the
required documents to the Hong Kong Immigration Department on your
behalf. Please upload a legible scan copy of the visa application form and the
relevant documents to the online application portal. Subsequent to the
uploading, students are required to send the original documents to GEO by
 post.
It usually takes 4 - 6 weeks to process a visa application. When the visa is
issued, we will collect it and send it to the address as indicated on your
online Application. Please inform GEO immediately if you have changed
your address.
accommodations_info:
Exchange students are guaranteed accommodation at the University-
managed Accommodation (including the Student Halls and Off-campus
 Housing) for a twin-sharing room, no single room is available.
Application instructions will be sent to successful applicants in the admission
 email. Application period is usually in early August and early December.
Details can be found at https://www.polyu.edu.hk/sao/student-resources-
and-support-section/residential-life/
cost_of_living:

- Food: HK$3,000

The monthly estimate of total living expenses is HK$6,000.

visa_info: Exchange students who study for one semester only (less than 6 months) are not required to apply for a study permit. accommodations_info: It is recommended that you purchase a comprehensive travel insurance for the full duration of your stay abroad, including your personal travel within/outside Canada. Please review the insurance coverages to ensure that they meet your needs. Students can purchase additional health and/or travel insurance from their preferred agent.
cost_of_living: Please refer to the website of Dalhousie University for information on cost of living during the exchange programme.

module_restrictions: Undergraduate exchange students cannot take classes in any business department (including Accounting, Administration, Economics, Entrepreneurship, Finance, Management, Management Information Systems, or Marketing). Some departments have specific restrictions as well.
visa_info: Students attending the university in another status (not J-1) must upload proof of status in the Immigration Documentation e-form. After receiving the I-20, students must pay the SEVIS I-901 fee and apply for a J-1 student visa (except for citizens of Canada and Bermuda).
accommodations_info: The University of Arizona has two offices on campus to assist students with housing options: Residence Life for on-campus housing and Off-Campus Housing for off-campus living options and resources. Housing is not guaranteed, but early applicants are usually provided with housing.
cost_of_living: Tuition is waived for exchange students. The estimated monthly living expenses can be found at https://financialaid.arizona.edu/freshmen/estimated-cost-attendance.

module_restrictions: Undergraduate classes are numbered 100-499. You must meet pre-requisites to enrol in a class.
visa_info: Exchange students are eligible to apply for a J-1 or F-1 Visa. Health Insurance coverage is compulsory.
accommodations_info: All exchange students are guaranteed housing and required to live on campus. Housing options include Woodstock Village, Riverside Apartments, and Townhouse Apartments. Students are responsible for providing their own kitchenware, cookware, bedding, and linens.
cost_of_living: Exchange students do not pay tuition. You pay for your living expenses (housing and food) as well as other entertainment types (travel, books, incidental, and health insurance) of expenses.

visa_info: Exchange students must apply to New Zealand Immigration for a student visa and obtain the visa before entering New Zealand. Please note that it is NOT possible for exchange students to travel to New Zealand on a visitor's visa and apply for a student permit upon arrival in New Zealand, even if you are a citizen of a country with which New Zealand has a visa waiver agreement. It is imperative that all exchange students get their student visa BEFORE travelling to New Zealand, as you may be refused a student permit if you apply from within New Zealand. Students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university. This is to ensure that you can obtain your visa in time before the start of your exchange term. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country. For more information on visa applications, please refer to https://www.immigration.govt.nz/new-zealand-visas/options/study
cost_of_living: The University of Canterbury does not provide a specific breakdown of the cost of living. However, students are advised to consider expenses such as accommodation, meals, transport, books, stationery, personal expenses, and any additional insurance they may require. The total cost of living will vary depending on individual preferences and circumstances.

module_restrictions: Business, Economics and Management modules at Vilnius are excluded from the exchange between NUS and Vilnius. Limited courses are also available at the Lithuanian Academy of Music & Theatre and Vilnius Academy of Fine Arts.
visa_info: Non-degree students from non-EU countries must get national Type D Visa prior to arrival in Lithuania. The necessary documents to be submitted to the Migration Department or the nearest Lithuanian Embassy: 1. Completed application (https://visa.vrm.lt/epm/); 2. Letter of Acceptance from Vilnius University 3. Visa application processing fee (if applicable); 4. Proofs of sufficient means of support (at least €200 per month + €400 for the return journey); 5. 1 photo (colour, 35 x 45mm); 6. Valid passport; 7. Health insurance valid in Schengen countries (minimum coverage of €30,000). 8. Letter of mediation (will be sent via e-mail by Vilnius University together with the Letter of Acceptance; validity 1 month )
accommodations_info: Dormitories are situated in Saulėtekio, Olandų or Didlaukio Street which can be around 20 minutes bus ride from the main campus at Vilnius’ old town. The time taken to reach a faculty depends on their geographical location and the traffic conditions. Only twin or triple sharing rooms are available. A group of five to six students will share a common bathroom. Common kitchens will be shared by around 20 students. There will be no gender division based on room, floor or building. Students can request to share rooms with the same gender. There will be 24/7 security officer manning the reception area of every dormitory building. Online application for accommodation must be submitted at least one month before the scheduled arrival.
cost_of_living: The estimated monthly living expenses at Vilnius University can be found at http://www.vu.lt/en/studies/practical-information/56-studies/studies/2507

Eligibility and suitability of the modules depends on the pre-requisites as well as the examination date for individual modules which you wish to take at TUM.

accommodations_info: For more information about accommodation, please refer to https://www.international.tum.de/en/global/accommodation/. Due to the housing shortage in Munich, please take note that student accommodation might not be available. Students who secure the student accommodation managed by the Studentenwerk München are expected to commit to a stated duration of stay on contract. The contract could end in late July, late August, or in September and there is no guarantee that there will be a vacancy for your preferred contract end date. module_restrictions: UMD is suitable for FASS, FoS and SoC students. However, SoC modules are limited at UMD. Students should plan to take two, possibly three CS modules, but have plenty of back-ups in mind.
visa_info:
Once admitted to UMD, exchange students will request a DS-2019 Form using the International Student and Scholar Services office (ISSS) online portal, iTerp. The DS-2019 form is the immigration document required to apply for a J-1 Visa.

Proof of Financial Support
You will need to submit Proof of Financial Support to iTerp. The anticipated proof of finance amount that students need to show for the 2017-2018 academic year is:
$15,750 minimum for students studying at UMD for the full year
$7,000 minimum for students studying at UMD for one semester only.
You can demonstrate proof of financial support in the following ways:
A bank statement on bank letterhead signed by a bank official with the applicant’s full name listed as the account holder (first and last name).
If the bank statement is not in the matriculating student's name, a letter of support must be submitted and signed by a sponsor stating that the sponsor is accepting full financial responsibility for the applicant accompanied by a bank statement on bank letterhead signed by a bank official with the sponsor’s full name listed as the account holder.
A scholarship letter from the sponsoring organization listing the amount of the award and the student’s full name (first and last name).
Bank statements or letters must be dated within 6 months of the date the application is submitted. You cannot submit statements from investment accounts or loan agencies. It must be a regular checking or savings account from which applicants or sponsors can withdraw money at any time.
accommodations_info: For information on the cost of housing and dining plans available please visit the Department of Residence Life and Dining Services websites. You can also view the estimated cost of attendance as an exchange student at UMD.
cost_of_living: Tuition fees are waived for exchange students. For more information on the cost of attending UMD for a semester, please refer to the following link: https://www.financialaid.umd.edu/award_process/cost_of_attendance.html

module_restrictions: First year and second year undergraduate students are not accepted at U Tokyo due to the internal structure of the university. Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences and Faculty of Medicine are not open to exchange students. Graduate courses are generally not applicable for undergraduate students.
visa_info: Upon acceptance, U Tokyo will apply for a Certificate of Eligibility on your behalf with the Japanese Ministry of Justice, and send it to you when issued. The certificate is required for you to apply for a study visa. Exchange students must obtain a “College Student” visa for the duration of their study in Japan. Please visit the Japan Embassy website for the required supporting documents for your visa application. All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university. This is to ensure that you can obtain your visa in time before the start of your exchange term. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country.
accommodations_info: Exchange students may apply for university housing arranged by U Tokyo which are located off-campus. University housing is not guaranteed due to limited capacity. U Tokyo will contact students about housing application procedures after their exchange applications have been approved. For more information about accommodation, please refer to [http://www.u-tokyo.ac.jp/en/administration/housing-office/index.html](http://www.u-tokyo.ac.jp/en/administration/housing-office/index.html)

module_restrictions: Medicine, Nursing, Pharmacy, Law, Teacher Education, Information Security (Cyber Defense), Art & Design and all courses at Sejong Campus are not open to exchange students. Undergraduate students are not allowed to take postgraduate courses. KU is experiencing high demand for Business and Management courses. Therefore the chances of enrolling into these courses are very slim. NUS Business students should apply via the faculty-level SEP agreement in order to take Business courses at KU.
visa_info: Exchange students must apply for a D2 student visa before arrival in Korea. After you received the Certificate of Admission (CoA) and offer letter from your host university, you may proceed to the Korean Embassy to apply for the student visa, with the relevant supporting documents. All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university. This is to ensure that you can obtain your visa in time before the start of your exchange term. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country.
accommodations_info:
On-campus accommodation is available but limited. There are two types of on-campus halls of residence at KU – CJ International House (I-House) or Anam Hall 2. Most of the rooms are shared rooms. The on-campus accommodation is located within 20 minutes-walk to the main campus.

Exchange students are advised to apply as soon as possible as rooms are allocated to students on first-come-first-served basis. For more information about accommodation, please refer to https://gsc.korea.ac.kr/usr/service/accommodation.do

There is a wide range of off-campus housing available within close proximity to KU.

module_restrictions: Students are allowed to take courses offered by other departments/institutes, in addition to those of their own departments/institutes. They can also take courses of different program years and levels. Undergraduate students may take graduate courses, and vice versa.
visa_info: Students whose exchange period is one semester (or less than 180 days) will have to apply for a Visitor Visa while students whose exchange period is more than 180 days will have to apply for a Resident Visa. Chinese, Hong Kong and Macau passport holders will need to apply for a Taiwan Entry Permit.
accommodations_info: On-campus accommodation is available to exchange students. After applications are accepted by NCKU, applicants will be prompted by email to sign up for on-campus accommodation online. Please note that space of the on-campus accommodation is not guaranteed, and students will be responsible for their own housing expenses. To have a quick review of NCKU on-campus dormitory designated to exchange students, please take a look at Ching-Yeh 3 Dorm, which offers double rooms to international students.

module_restrictions: NA
visa_info: Singapore passport holders may enter Croatia with a valid passport before applying for a residence permit in Zagreb. Students are advised to check with the Croatian embassy on the documentation required and bring them along with you. List of embassies and consulates: https://konzuliszolgalat.kormany.hu/hu-missions-abroad. Students have to obtain the entry visa – ‘RESIDENCE VISA FOR STUDY PURPOSES before departure from their home country. Among the others, students must present the Letter of Acceptance from BME, proof of payment of the institution fee, proof of accommodation in Budapest and a passport validity of at least an additional year upon your arrival. Processing of the residence visa is expected to take a minimum of 2 weeks (or longer). The visa will be valid for 30 days. Upon their arrival in Budapest, students have another 30 days to apply for their residence permit (after registration at the university).
accommodations_info: BME does not offer accommodation to incoming students at the university’s dormitories. Students are required to source for their accommodation for the duration of their exchange. BME can only assist incoming students in finding their accommodation. Private accommodation (rented room/apartment) is available for between 300-400 EUR (inclusive of utilities) per month, depending on location and comfort. BME ESN (ERASMUS Student Network, esn.bme.hu) runs a temporary office assisting students with finding and arranging accommodation at the beginning of the terms.
cost_of_living:
The estimated monthly living expenses in Budapest are as follows:

- Accommodation: 400 EUR
- Food and misc expenses: 170 EUR to 270 EUR
- Health insurance: 120 EUR (per semester)

module_restrictions: At Imperial, the timetables for classes are often not approved until September. Therefore, it is not possible to confirm any programme of study until you have arrived at the College. Students are encouraged to take courses offered by the same department at the same level to avoid potential clash of timetable. For example, it is recommended that you take all year 2 courses at Department of Electronic and Electrical Engineering. Imperial is also unable to offer study plans involving teaching from more than one department or from both the undergraduate curriculum (BEng/MEng/BSc/MSci) and postgraduate curriculum (MSc/MRes). Course Catalogues: The most recent and relevant syllabus information (electronic documents or departmental web links) continue to be available from the relevant departmental student exchange co-ordinator responsible for individual exchange links.
visa_info: UK Visa and Immigration updates their immigration policy regularly. It is the student’s responsibility to check on the requirements via their website before they leave for the exchange. https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/uk-visas-and-immigration For latest information on border control please see: https://www.gov.uk/uk-border-control Students must obtain a Student Visa for a full year exchange in Imperial. To apply for Student Visa, please refer to “Guidance/Information Document for Nominated Exchange Students” for more information. Applicants should ensure that they are fully aware of what they will need to do in order to successfully apply for a Student Visa. The CAS statement will contain a number that allows student to apply for a Student Visa. The application for Student Visa can take up to three months and students are advised to apply for the visa in advance of their intended date of travel to the UK. Specific questions concerning visas can be addressed to the Imperial’s International Student Support Team: international@imperial.ac.uk. More information can be found at http://www.imperial.ac.uk/study/international-students/visas-and-immigration/applying-for-a-student-visa-overseas/ Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country.
accommodations_info: The “Guidance/Information Document for Nominated Exchange Students” also cover issues such as Accommodation and Orientation for when a student is successful with their application. Please note that the Imperial College London is normally only able to guarantee the offer of a room in a College hall of residence to undergraduate exchange students who accept admission for a full academic year and who have met any conditions of entry which may apply (see guidance for full details). Students can apply for Imperial’s accommodation once they receive the conditional offer from Imperial via Student e-Service. A student will be invited by email to apply for accommodation in a College hall of residence. The accommodation will be guaranteed for the full academic year if students submit the online accommodation application form by Imperial’s deadline and have met in full any conditions of entry (e.g. English language) and confirm their admission on Student e-Service by Imperials’ deadline. Please note that Imperial issue the Confirmation of Acceptance for Studies (CAS) – for inclusion in a visa application - when appropriate and this might be after 23 August. The issuing of the CAS does not influence the accommodation application routine.
cost_of_living: Students can find information and advice on living costs at managing your money (UG) and details can also be found at http://www.imperial.ac.uk/study/ug/fees-and-funding/managing-your-money/living-costs/

module_restrictions: Not all courses are available in English. Time-table clashes may occur if taking modules from different faculties. It is recommended to take at least 50% of classes in the main major.
visa_info: EU citizens and citizens from several countries do not need a visa to enter Germany. Students from other countries must apply for a Student Applicant’s visa. Visa application process can take up to 2 months.
accommodations_info: The Studentenwerk Seezeit is the biggest provider of student housing in Konstanz, offering more than 1,800 places in their Halls of Residence. Rents range from €230 to €380 per month. Private housing options are available as well.

university_name: University of Tuebingen (Eberhard Karls Universität Tübingen)
faculties_accepted: Faculty of Economics and Social Sciences
module_restrictions: Courses from Faculty Medicine is not open to exchange students. Availability in beginner’s German language courses (A1/A2 level) are limited and cannot be guaranteed. Students who wish to study at Tuebingen Faculty of Science (= Natural Sciences) need to submit supporting documents such as a language certificate, Transcript of Records and Study Plan with a course list that can be sent to the Tuebingen Faculty of Science for approval.
visa_info: EU citizens and citizens from the following countries do not need a visa to enter Germany: Australia, Canada, Honduras, Iceland, Israel, Japan, Korea, Liechtenstein, Monaco, New Zealand, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland and the United States. However, after entering Germany, you will have to apply for a residence permit at the local "Auslaenderbehörde" (Immigration Office) if you are staying for more than three months. Students from all other countries must apply for a visa for study purposes via the German diplomatic representation in their home country. You must not under any circumstances travel to Germany on a tourist visa.
accommodations_info: Accommodation is administered by the Studierendenwerk (Student Services Organization), which is not affiliated with the University. You could possibly get the university accommodation if you submit an application before the deadline which will be mentioned in Tuebingen’s acceptance email. For an overview of the dormitories, please see: https://en.my-stuwe.de/housing/halls-of-residence-tuebingen/ All rooms for exchange students are fully furnished single rooms with shared kitchen and usually shared bathrooms. Students who have contract that ends in August or September are expected to pay for the rental until August or September. There will be no refund of the rental if you leave the student accommodation earlier. Deposit for the student accommodation will only be returned to you after you have fulfilled the conditions for the full refund of deposit. It takes approximately four months for the rental deposit (if applicable) to be returned to you.
