module_restrictions: Exchange students may not enrol in courses offered at the BU Medical School, School of Dental Medicine, Law School, Graduate School of Management, and Kilachand Honors College.
visa_info: All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they receive the official offer letter/email from their host university. Some visa application processes can take up to 2 months to process. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country. If you are traveling on a passport issued by a country other than the USA, you should check with the nearest consulate of the country to which you are traveling or transferring through on a connecting flight in order to determine whether a visa will be required. Do this as far in advance as possible and notify our office of the documentation you will need to apply for your visa. Also check with the local consulate of your home country to determine whether there are any passport or travel regulations of which you need to be aware. Investigate whether you will need to apply for a new visa to re-enter the United States, if you plan to do so upon completion of the program. The Boston University Office of International Students and Scholars (ISSO) administers visa documentation. International students who are accepted to a BU exchange program must obtain a J-1 visa. Upon acceptance, the ISSO will issue each exchange student a SEVIS Form DS-2019. Students must bring the form to the nearest American Embassy/Consulate in their country to obtain a visa.
accommodations_info: Upon acceptance exchange students will receive a brochure outlining Boston University on-campus housing options and costs. Residence rates are assessed based on the type of room or apartment to which a student is assigned. In dormitory-style residences, there are seven different room types–single, double, triple, and quad rooms that have either shared bathrooms on a floor or private bathrooms within a room or suite. In apartment-style residences, there are five different types of accommodations–single- or multiple-occupancy bedroom apartments, all with bathrooms and kitchens. Dining plan rates vary depending on the dining plan selected. Students assigned to dormitory-style residences are required to choose one of the six dining plans. Visit the BU Housing website for more information on on-campus housing options. Note: Exchange student may choose to live off-campus; if you choose to live off campus you are responsible for finding your own housing.
cost_of_living: According to the information available on the Boston University website, exchange students can refer to the Budgeting Tab on the following page for information on the estimated monthly living expenses: http://www.bu.edu/abroad/plan/financial-aid/. Exchange students can deduct the cost of tuition which they will not need to pay to BU.

module_restrictions: Business, Law and Military Studies modules at the University of Zagreb are not opened to NUS students participating in the Exchange Programme in Zagreb. Economics modules offered at University of Zagreb reside at the Faculty of Economics and Business. The Economics modules are more literature-based and not mathematical or statistical-based.
visa_info: Singapore passport holders may enter Croatia with a valid passport before applying for a residence permit in Zagreb. Students are advised to check with the Croatian embassy on the documentation required and bring them along with you. Students coming from a country that has a visa-regime with Croatia will be required to apply for a visa via the Croatian embassy in their home county before departing for Croatia. Students who need an entry visa to the Republic of Croatia need to regulate their residence permit before coming to Zagreb at the nearest Croatian embassy. Students who are not obliged to possess a visa to enter the Republic of Croatia may stay in Croatia for a maximum of 90 days within a period of 6 months, starting from the day of their first entry. Exchange students staying in Croatia for more than 90 days are obliged to apply for the approval of the temporary stay for the purpose of studies (dozvola boravka) within 48 hours of their arrival.
accommodations_info: The University of Zagreb does not guarantee that exchange students are given accommodation in the student residences. Exchange students may choose between organized accommodation in the 3 student hall of residence and will need to apply for it. All rooms are on a twin-sharing basis (there is no option to stay in a single room). The bathroom is shared. Cutlery and utensils are not provided. Complimentary Internet access is provided for all rooms.
cost_of_living: The cost of living in Zagreb varies depending on the individual lifestyle and spending habits. On average, students can expect to spend around [estimated monthly living expenses]. This includes accommodation, meals, transportation, textbooks, and other personal expenses. It is recommended to set aside a sufficient budget to cover living expenses for the duration of the exchange program.

module_restrictions: Exchange students may select any of the courses offered within the college that they are admitted into, granted there is availability and that they meet the prerequisites.
visa_info: After admitted students commit to studying at Pitt as either an international exchange or guest student from the Study Abroad Office, students will receive information from the Office of International Services (OIS) regarding the overall visa application process. As non-degree-seeking, international students, exchange or guest, will typically receive a J-1 visa status for the duration of study. OIS will then direct you to initiate the overall visa process through their online portal myOIS.pitt.edu. Visit the J-1 Visa Exchange Visitor Program website for general information as well as a list of required documents for the application.
accommodations_info: On-campus housing is NOT guaranteed for exchange students. For those living off-campus, students exchanging for one semester should sublet or find a roommate who may be searching for someone to fill a vacancy as most apartment leases are for a full-year.
cost_of_living: The estimated monthly expenses for living in Pittsburgh can be found at http://internationalexchanges.pitt.edu/costs. Please note that the cost of living may vary and it is recommended to refer to the provided link for the most up-to-date information.

module_restrictions: Postgraduate modules are not open to undergraduate exchange students. Medicine, Dentistry and Veterinary Science are not open to exchange students.
visa_info:
UK Visa and Immigration updates their immigration policy regularly. It is the student’s responsibility to check on the requirements via their website before they leave for the exchange. Please refer to the following links for more information:
https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/uk-visas-and-immigration
https://www.gov.uk/uk-border-control
accommodations_info: Students who have already been accepted by Bristol for the Study Abroad Programme should refer to the email received when they accepted their offer for the link to the Accommodation Application Form. For more information, please visit: https://www.bristol.ac.uk/global-opportunities/at-bristol/student-life/accommodation/
cost_of_living: The estimated living expenses per month can be found at http://www.bristol.ac.uk/fees-funding/advice/living-expenses/.
module_transfer: Modules approved in the past might not be offered by the host university or approved by your Faculty when it is time for your exchange. Please check the latest course offerings at the host universities while you are preparing your Study Plan.
exam_info: Semester 1 exchange students are expected to stay in Bristol for their exams which could take place in late January. Alternative assessments can sometimes be arranged but are not guaranteed. Please contact global-opportunities@bristol.ac.uk if you have any questions. Semester 2 students are required to be in Bristol for the May/June exam period. Bristol modules which run for the full year are assessed at the end of the academic year only.
language_requirements: Bristol do not currently ask for English Language Proficiency documentation from NUS students. However, NUS students should be prepared to submit documentation if required (e.g. photocopies of GCE 'O' level certificate with English language of grade C or better, IB English with 5 or better, or certificate for Singapore Integrated Programme Cambridge 'A' Levels (SIPCAL) with General Paper of Grade C or better). Bristol reserves the right, in individual circumstances, to specify an additional language requirement for an applicant if it is felt to be necessary.

module_restrictions: Courses within Nutrition and Health Sciences, Geoscience, courses at the University Centre in Svalbard and Psychology might have restrictions and prerequisites may apply. Courses with the codes ENG and NORAM tend to get fully booked quite fast, and Oslo degree-seeking students who have these courses as compulsory in their programme are given priority.
visa_info:
All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university. Some visa application process could take up to 2 months to process. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country.
Non-EU/EEA-citizens
Students residing outside the European Economic Area must apply for a visa and residence permit immediately after they have received their Letter of Admission from the University of Oslo. All Non-EU/EEA students are advised to apply for a residence permit from home.
How to apply:
Fill in the application form for first time residence permit and apply through the nearest Norwegian Embassy/Consulate in your country of residence. (This is managed by VFS in Singapore.)
Be sure to include the following documents together with the application form:
- Passport and copy of all used pages in passport
- 2 new/recent passport size photos with white background
- A letter of full-time admission from an approved educational institution, stating your name, which studies you have admission to, at what level the studies are and how long the programme lasts
- Documentation that you have sufficient funds
- Documentation which shows that you have somewhere to live in Norway
- UDI’s checklist
You must register with the Oslo Police, Foreign Section within 7 days after arrival.
accommodations_info: Prices for a single, furnished room vary from approximately NOK 2,200 to NOK 4,200 a month. International students are generally offered accommodation in the lower price range, where they share bathrooms (2-5 students) and kitchens (4-6 students). However, they may apply for transfer at a later date if they should wish to change their accommodation within the same category. Please note that family apartments or flats for students who wish to bring along their spouse or family cannot be guaranteed by SiO or the International Education Office. Students who wish to bring along their spouse or family have to find an apartment on the open market. These days, rents start at approx NOK 8,000 for a 2-room apartment in central Oslo.

module_restrictions: Only life science and natural science modules are available in English. Otherwise, students need to know German in order to have a wider range of modules to choose from.
visa_info: EU citizens and citizens from the following countries do not need a visa to enter Germany: Australia, Canada, Honduras, Iceland, Israel, Japan, Korea, Liechtenstein, Monaco, New Zealand, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland and the United States. However, after entering Germany, you will have to apply for a residence permit at the local 'Auslaenderbehörde' (Immigration Office) if you are staying for more than three months. Students from all other countries must apply for a visa for study purposes via the German diplomatic representation in their home country. You must not under any circumstances travel to Germany on a tourist visa. All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university. Some visa application process could take up to 2 months to process. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country.
accommodations_info: Students from the University of Hohenheim could be allocated a room at one of several halls of residences run by Student Services Tuebingen-Hohenheim. However only a limited number of rooms are reserved for international students (non-European nationals). There is a high demand for these rooms, which is why only a small number of applications will be successful. In addition to halls of residences, there are flat-sharing communities, small apartments and other forms of communal living. Students who have a contract that ends in August or September are expected to pay for the rental until August or September. There will be no refund of the rental if you leave the student accommodation earlier.
cost_of_living:
The estimated monthly breakdown of costs are as follows:
- Accommodation: €250 - €300
- Insurance: €65
- Food: €150 - €200
- Others (Books, entertainment etc.): €165

The monthly estimate for living expenses is €630 - €730. Exchange students are also required to pay administrative and Student Services fees, as well as contribute to the Student Parliament, totaling about €162.80 per semester. To receive a residence permit, students must show proof of financial support with at least €735 per month of stay.

visa_info: UK Visa and Immigration updates their immigration policy regularly. It is the student’s responsibility to check on the requirements via their website before they leave for the exchange. https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/uk-visas-and-immigration For latest information on border control please see: https://www.gov.uk/uk-border-control Standard Visitor Visa for Semester Exchange If you are a Singapore citizen or a citizen of another country on the UK non-visa nationals list, and if your course of studies is less than 6 months, you will request entry to the UK as a Standard Visitor when you arrive. Singapore citizens do not normally need to meet with a Border Force agent, and will be able to enter the UK through E-gates. The E-gates will automatically grant you permission to stay in the UK for up to 6 months. You will not receive a stamp on your passport thus it is important that you retain evidence of when you entered the UK. Hence, please keep your boarding pass or evidence of your flight itinerary. Please refer here for more details on the Standard Visitor Visa. Student Visa for Full-Year Exchange You need a Student Visa for a full-year exchange in UCL. For more details on visa application, read the information available here. All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university. Some visa application processes can take up to 2 months to process. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country.
accommodations_info: Once you have accepted your offer to study at UCL, UCL will send you more information about accommodation. UCL guarantees accommodation to exchange students who have been accepted to study at UCL for a full academic year, provided that they submit their housing application form by the deadline set by the Student Residences Office. Students who study at UCL for less than a full academic year are not guaranteed university accommodation. We recommend that you apply for accommodation as soon as possible after you have received your offer. On-Campus Accommodation: Please note that all inquiries about housing at UCL should be directed to the Student Residences Office. The information on accommodation and its FAQ can be found at: http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/accommodation Private Accommodation: Independent organisations offering accommodation to students in London can be found at https://housing.london.ac.uk/. UCL collaborates with a number of independent organisations offering private accommodation to students in London. Please see here for more information. Alternatively, students can arrive 2-3 weeks before term begins in order to search for suitable accommodation. There is enormous demand for accommodation in London. The search starts in August and increases throughout September/October. Students should note that it is always advisable to view private accommodation in advance and read the fine print in order to ascertain that it suits your requirements.
cost_of_living: Information on cost of living can be found at https://www.ucl.ac.uk/scholarships/how-much-does-it-cost-study-ucl. visa_info:
Upon receiving your DS-2019, you will need to apply for your J-1 visa at a U.S. consulate or embassy. We recommend you visit the website of the US Embassy/Consulate where you wish to apply for your visa, and follow the procedures for documentation, interview request, etc. In general, you will need to present:

1. A valid passport from your own government.
2. A "Certificate of Eligibility" for a temporary stay in the U.S. (Form DS-2019 by Rice University or another sponsor).
3. Financial documents to prove you have the funds required for at least a year’s stay in the U.S. (as indicated on the DS-2019).
4. Proof of payment of the SEVIS fee. All J-1 visa applicants need to pay the one time SEVIS fee prior to applying for a visa. Keep your receipt as proof of payment to present to the US Consulate, port of entry officials when entering the U.S., OISS upon check-in, and for your records. For more information visit: www.FMJfee.com.
5. Completed visa application forms – be sure to indicate your name as stated on your passport and your DS-2019 documents to better ensure that your name on your visa stamp will be displayed properly.

visa_info: Students must apply for the J-1 visa. The Certificate of Non-Immigrant Eligibility for J status is the DS-2019. This is also a non-immigrant visa status. The rules for the J-1 are similar to the F-1. However, there are two important differences. Those in J-1 status may be subject to what is referred to as the "two-year home residency requirement" or subject to 212(e) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The other difference is that dependents may apply for work permission. The two-year home residency requirement means that those individuals must return home for two years before applying for the H, L, or permanent residency visas. In addition, those subject to the two-year home residency requirement cannot change status to another within the U.S. A J-1 becomes subject to 212(e) by coming from a country and studying a field on the skills list, being sponsored by the U.S. government or the home country government, or studying in a program for graduate medical education.

If granted, the Housing Assignments Office will send an on-line housing contract to the FPS account for the applicant’s review and acceptance. Details about housing and meal plans, including cost, are available on the Housing website. Students can visit Off-Campus Living to find resources for accommodation off campus.

module_restrictions: MBA and the Master of Law programmes are not open to exchange students. Cross faculty modules are allowed but should not exceed 8 credits. Courses conducted by Academy of Arts and Design and Physical training courses are not open to exchange students; LLM, MBA, MPA, courses taught in English offered by the School of Architecture are not open to exchange students.
visa_info: Exchange students in China are required to apply for student visa (X2 visa for those intending to study in China for a period of no more than 180 days and X1 visa for those intending to study in China for a period of more than 180 days). You will receive the admission letter and visa application form (JW202) once you are accepted by the host university for the student exchange programme. Exchange students are required to apply for the student visa in person at the China Visa Application Service Centre in Singapore with the relevant documents before the start of the academic semester. China Visa Application Service Centre in Singapore: https://www.visaforchina.cn/SGP2_EN/index.shtml
accommodations_info: Tsinghua will prioritise university-level exchange students with on-campus accommodation at Zijing Foreign Student Apartments. The apartment charges different prices for different room types. Typical double room charges RMB 40 per day and single room charges RMB 80 per day. Students may visit https://www.tsinghua.edu.cn/en/Campus/Student_Life/Housing___Dining.htm for more details. As there are limited on-campus accommodation, exchange students who have received Tsinghua University’s Admission Notice are required to reserve the rooms in advance by the specific deadline and to follow the application instructions found in the Foreign Students Dormitory Application System along with the admission package.
cost_of_living: The cost of living in Tsinghua University varies depending on individual spending and lifestyle choices. Generally, students should budget for accommodation, meals, transportation, books, and personal expenses. Accommodation in on-campus student apartments can cost RMB 40 per day for a double room and RMB 80 per day for a single room. Additional costs may include meals, which can range from RMB 20-30 per day, transportation expenses, textbooks, and personal expenses. It is recommended for students to budget approximately RMB 5,000 to RMB 15,000 per semester for living expenses during the exchange programme.

visa_info: Exchange students who study for one semester only (less than 6 months) are not required to apply for a study permit. However, depending on your country of citizenship, you may have to apply for an eTA OR a visitor visa. For more information on visa applications, please refer to https://www.cic.gc.ca/english/visit/visas.asp.
accommodations_info: All incoming exchange students are automatically enrolled in the guard.me@UVic plan upon course registration at UVic. It is recommended that you purchase a comprehensive travel insurance for the full duration of your stay abroad, including your personal travel within/outside Canada. Please review the insurance coverages to ensure that they meet your needs. Students can purchase additional health and/or travel insurance from their preferred agent.

module_restrictions: Communications, Economics, Psychology, Design, and Law, Societies & Justice courses in particular are extremely competitive so you should plan to take courses outside of these areas. Courses in Architecture, Education, Law and Health Sciences are generally available to graduate students only. Professional programs including Dentistry, Medicine, Nursing, and Pharmacy as well as many studio classes are not open to exchange students.
visa_info: UW’s International Student Services (ISS) Office will be your main point of contact for all items related to your visa and maintaining your immigration status. For more information, please refer here: https://iss.washington.edu/travel-visas/visas/
accommodations_info: As an incoming exchange student to the University of Washington, you are free to make your own housing arrangements. To help you decide which option is best for you, please review the various housing options at the following link: https://www.washington.edu/studyabroad/visitingexchange/practical-matters/housing/
cost_of_living: According to the University of Washington's estimated monthly living expenses, the cost of attendance includes housing, food, transportation, books and supplies, personal care, and other miscellaneous expenses. Please refer to the following link for more information: http://www.washington.edu/studyabroad/visitingexchange/practical-matters/cost-of-attendance/

visa_info: All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university. Some visa application process could take up to 2 months to process. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country. Visa is required for a stay of more than 90 days for Singaporean and Malaysians. Non-EU students wishing to study in Poland should apply for an entry visa. All students should legalize their stay exceeding 3 months by obtaining temporary residence permit after their arrival to Poland. More information on http://www.msz.gov.pl
accommodations_info: CUT does not guarantee accommodation to exchange students. Applicants who need accommodation should submit their accommodation application to CUT’s International Relations Office before 30 May, regardless of whether the study period commences in the winter or spring semester of the following academic year. Co-educative student on-campus housing refers to double rooms with shared bathrooms (each bathroom is shared by four students) and shared kitchen. Students may check in our dormitories a few days before the semester starts. Fall Semester: after 16 September, Spring Semester: after 16 February. For more information, please refer to http://iro.pk.edu.pl/accommodation/ and http://www.akademiki.pk.edu.pl/ds4-balon.html (page only in Polish).

visa_info: Exchange students who study for one semester only (less than 6 months) are not required to apply for a study permit. However, depending on your country of citizenship, you may have to apply for an eTA OR a visitor visa. For more information on visa applications, please refer to https://www.cic.gc.ca/english/visit/visas.asp.
accommodations_info: Exchange students will be enrolled in two health insurance plans while on exchange in Canada. The University Health Insurance Plan (UHIP) covers basic health care services, such as medical doctor appointments, hospital visits, and most diagnostic tests. The Studentcare extended Health and Dental Plan covers extra costs like prescription drugs, paramedical practitioners, vision, and dental care. It is recommended that you purchase a comprehensive travel insurance for the full duration of your stay abroad, including your personal travel within/outside Canada. Please review the insurance coverages to ensure that they meet your needs. Students can purchase additional health and/or travel insurance from their preferred agent.
cost_of_living: There is no specific information provided about the cost of living in the PDF text.

module_restrictions: Exchange students who are not nominated as Business students are discouraged from taking any Business or Economics courses offered at the Innsbruck’s School of Management. Innsbruck’s International Economic and Business Studies Office (IWW – office) is a separate office and therefore requires separate nomination, application and processing. Students who wish to apply for courses from University of Innsbruck and from IWW have to be nominated twice, applied through two different application portals managed by Innsbruck and IWW and subjected to all restrictions from both Innsbruck and IWW. It is not possible to be registered for both Bachelor and Master programme and taking modules at both Bachelor and Master level in Innsbruck at the same time. NUS students applying for master courses at Innsbruck must include a copy of their bachelor certificate and transcripts of records of Bachelor programme.
visa_info: All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university. Some visa application process could take up to 2 months to process. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country. Exchange students who will be going for exchange for up to 6 months will have to apply for Apply for Visa-D (long-term visa – for stay of more than 90, but less than 180 days. Single entry / multiple entry). More information at https://www.uibk.ac.at/international-relations/exchange-students-incoming/preparation-arrival-in-ibk/#visa%20application
accommodations_info: Finding accommodation may be challenging in Innsbruck. Students should apply as soon as possible to get a room in a student home (Studentenheim). Summer term: application recommended in September
cost_of_living: The estimated monthly living expenses in Innsbruck are as follows: Accommodation: €350 - €450, Food: €250 - €400, Transport: €130, Books, entertainment, etc.: €100 - €200. The monthly estimate ranges from €830 - €1,180. [Details can be found at http://www.uibk.ac.at/international-relations/erasmus/incoming/guide-englisch.pdf]

visa_info: Once you have purchased the Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC), your host university will issue an Electronic Confirmation of Enrolment (eCoE), which is required for your Australian Student Visa Application. All exchange students must obtain an Australian Non Award Student Visa (sub-class 500) before arriving in Australia. Students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university. This is to ensure that you can obtain your visa in time before the start of your exchange term. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country. For more information on visa applications, please refer to https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/student-500.

module_restrictions: Medicine, Business, and Law courses are not open to exchange students.
visa_info: EU citizens and citizens from Australia, Canada, Honduras, Iceland, Israel, Japan, Korea, Liechtenstein, Monaco, New Zealand, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland, and the United States do not need a visa to enter Germany. Students from all other countries must apply for a visa for study purposes via the German diplomatic representation in their home country.
accommodations_info: There is no student accommodation offered by HUB in Berlin city. However, students could consider private apartments if they prefer to stay in the city. Halls of residence (Wohnheime) are located in various parts outside the city and vary in standard and price from €250 to €500 per month. The average traveling time from the student accommodation to HUB (central campus) is about 45 minutes to 1 hour on bus/train.
cost_of_living:
The estimated monthly living expenses for students in Berlin are as follows:

- Accommodation: €250 - €500
- Insurance: €80
- Food: €200 - €300
- Others (Books, entertainment, etc.): €300

The monthly estimate ranges from €830 to €1,180.

faculties_accepted: Faculty of Arts. Humanities and Cultures
School of Mathematics and Physical Sciences
module_restrictions: Graduate modules are not open to undergraduate exchange students. Studio Art, Design and Music Performance modules may not be available to exchange students. For highly popular modules, early application is strongly recommended to avoid disappointment. There are a number of other module restrictions so it is advised that the search parameter ‘Search by Incoming Study Abroad’ is used to obtain an accurate list of what is available. Leeds would also advise students to read the school-specific module guidance here.
visa_info: UK Visa and Immigration updates their immigration policy regularly. It is the student’s responsibility to check on the requirements via their website before they leave for the exchange. Standard Visitor Visa for Semester Exchange: If you are a Singapore citizen or a citizen of another country on the UK non-visa nationals list, and if your course of studies is less than 6 months, you will request entry to the UK as a Standard Visitor when you arrive. Singapore citizens do not normally need to meet with a Border Force agent, and will be able to enter the UK through E-gates. The E-gates will automatically grant you permission to stay in the UK for up to 6 months. You will not receive a stamp on your passport thus it is important that you retain evidence of when you entered the UK. Hence, please keep your boarding pass or evidence of your flight itinerary. Student Visa for Full-Year Exchange: You need a Student Visa for a full-year exchange in Leeds.
accommodations_info: Information about university accommodation will be given in the acceptance email sent out by Leeds directly to selected students. Accommodation is guaranteed for all exchange students at the university provided that the application is received by the university's accommodation office before the given deadline. Students can apply for accommodation from mid-May after formally accepted by Leeds for the exchange. For details on the various housing options and rental, please refer here.
cost_of_living: The estimated monthly living expenses can be found at http://students.leeds.ac.uk/info/21504/living_in_the_uk/842/budget_and_costs. The breakdown and total cost of living can vary depending on personal preferences and lifestyle choices.

visa_info: Exchange students who study for one semester only (less than 6 months) are not required to apply for a study permit. However, depending on your country of citizenship, you may have to apply for an eTA OR a visitor visa. For more information on visa applications, please refer to https://www.cic.gc.ca/english/visit/visas.asp.

module_restrictions: Exchange students are eligible to take any UG course at Case, as long as they meet the pre-requisites and there is vacancy in the course. In general, 400 level courses and above are PG courses, and are not available to students participating in this exchange programme.
visa_info: All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they receive the official offer letter/email from their host university. Some visa application processes can take up to 2 months to process. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country.
accommodations_info: There are a variety of housing options available for students studying at Case Western Reserve University. You may choose to live in university-owned housing or in off-campus, privately-owned housing. Whichever you choose, you must secure housing before you arrive in the United States. Please note on-campus accommodation is not guaranteed. University-Owned Housing: Options for upper-class students include North and South Campus Residence Halls, the Village at 115th, North Property Management Apartments, the Apartments at 1576, and the Triangle Apartments. Details of these options are available at housing.case.edu. Students who wish to live in university housing can request placement through the New Student Checklist - when it becomes available. Please contact both the University Housing Office (housing@case.edu or +001 216-368-3780) and the Orientation Office (firstyearexperience@case.edu) for more information. Students who live on campus can have meals in campus dining halls. If desired, you will sign up for a meal plan as part of your housing application. The cost of the meal plan will vary depending on the plan you choose. Off-Campus Housing: Students also have the option to live off-campus in the University Circle area. Numerous off-campus options are available for you to explore. The Uptown Apartments, located minutes away from campus with convenient access to Uptown’s many shops and restaurants, are particularly popular. If you are interested in living off-campus you can search ALOHA, the Off-Campus Housing Listing Service available online: students.case.edu/services/aloha/. Students living off-campus move into their housing at the discretion of their housing agency. On-Campus Dining: Students who live on- or off-campus can have meals in campus dining halls. If desired, you will sign up for a meal plan as part of your housing application. The cost of the meal plan will vary depending on the plan you choose. Meal plan options are available at https://case.edu/dining/meal-plans/meal-plan-options. Living in University Circle: University Circle is a dynamic modern arts and cultural district. Home to a variety of museums, excellent restaurants, coffee shops, and festivals, there is always something to do in University Circle. Wade Oval hosts year-round outdoor programming including live concerts, movie nights, art walks, parades, and ice skating. *Note with all housing options - linens and towels are typically not included and should be planned for accordingly.
cost_of_living: The estimated monthly living expenses vary depending on individual lifestyles and spending habits, but on average, students can expect to spend around $1,500 to $2,000 per month. This includes accommodation, meals, transportation, books and supplies, personal expenses, and health insurance. Please note that tuition fees are waived for exchange students.

faculties_accepted: Engineering Sciences in Chemistry, Biotechnology and Health (CBH)
module_restrictions: Exchange students should read a total of 30 ECs per semester and not more. Exchange students are nominated by their home university but the final decision of acceptance is made by KTH and is based on the individual assessment of each application. A minimum requirement is that exchange students applying to KTH have completed at least two years of the educational programme at their home university, with grades above average. Courses for exchange students should be approved by the home university in a Learning Agreement or Study plan. Some courses have prerequisites and may be limited in terms of availability.
visa_info: Students from non EU/EEA countries need to apply for a residence permit for studies before entering Sweden. They must have a valid passport, be admitted to full-time studies, be able to support themselves for the planned study period, have comprehensive health insurance, and have a Letter of Acceptance from KTH. The application process may take up to three months. It is advised to apply as soon as the Letter of Acceptance is received.
accommodations_info: KTH has an Accommodation Office that rents rooms for exchange students in student housing buildings and apartment houses. The location of the room will depend on availability. The housing contract always terminates on July 31. If a student does not want the assigned room, they must find another room themselves and cancel the booking with KTH Accommodation at least one month before the contract starts. More information on accommodation can be found at [https://www.kth.se/en/studies/exchange/why-kth/accommodation-1.529520](https://www.kth.se/en/studies/exchange/why-kth/accommodation-1.529520).
cost_of_living: The estimated monthly living expenses in Stockholm, Sweden are as follows: Accommodation - SEK3,000 to SEK6,200, Food - SEK2,000, Transport - SEK590, Telephone/Internet - SEK300, Others (Entertainment, clothes) - SEK2,250. The total monthly estimate ranges from SEK8,140 to SEK11,310.

module_restrictions: Exchange/Visiting students are encouraged to maintain a flexible study plan with several alternate course selections to avoid disappointment if first-choice courses are unavailable. With the exception of specific course restrictions, and subject to prerequisite requirements, Exchange/Visiting students are free to select their courses. Students typically select courses within the academic area of their major at their home institution, although enrollment outside of your major is often possible, particularly with introductory-level courses that do not have prerequisites. Inbound exchange students are restricted from taking courses in Medicine, Law, Nursing, and Dental Hygiene. Graduate exchange students who want to take graduate level UHM courses in Second Language Studies (SLS) should have a TOEFL score of 100+. Students who want to take Business courses should already have a good foundation in business at their home university and a solid command of the English language, as normally demonstrated by a TOEFL score of 80+ (550+) or IELTS 6.5+.
visa_info: All international students (in F-1 and J-1 status) are required to begin the mandatory online Visa Clearance provided by UHM International Student Services (ISS). The online session is self-service and will take approximately 1 hour and 15 minutes to complete. Once you pass, download the certificate. The online visa clearance is only the first half of the process. To complete the visa clearance process, upon arriving in the US, you will need to sign up for a Visa Clearance Session, during which you will submit this certificate along with your passport, visa, DS-2019 or I-20, and J-1 Health Insurance Provider Form to the UHM International Student Services (ISS) Office for review. After your documents have been reviewed, you will be able to pick them up from the ISS Office. Failure to complete a Visa Clearance Session will result in a hold being placed on your MyUH course registration on the first day of instruction (but will not prevent you from registering in MyUH before the semester starts).
accommodations_info: On Campus Housing: Fall Semester – During the fall semester, there is a limited amount of on-campus housing available to international exchange students. Students coming to UHM for just the fall semester or for the academic year may apply for on-campus housing online, but are encouraged to explore off-campus housing options. Undergraduates are given preference for on-campus housing. Spring Semester – During the spring semester, on-campus housing is widely available. International exchange students coming to UHM for the spring semester or calendar year are welcome to apply for on-campus housing online, and have a high likelihood of being placed. Apply for On-Campus Housing – In order to apply for on-campus housing, you need a UH Number (found on your Acceptance letter). Students may apply for on-campus housing online at UHM Student Housing Services. There is a $25 application fee that should be paid with a credit card. Please be sure to use the “Non-Freshman” application form; do NOT use the “Freshman” application form. Please note that the housing contracts at UHM are for the entire academic year (two semesters). If you will only be studying at UHM for the Fall semester, that’s OK. We will inform Student Housing Services and later they will be able to release you from the second half of your contract. Off Campus Housing: Hawaii Student Suites – Several student-friendly properties, including “Beachwalk” apartments located one block from Waikiki Beach, and “Kalo Terrace” community dormitories located one block from the UHM campus. Off-Campus Housing Referral Program – This website lists several good options. The Off-Campus Housing Referral Program website includes much useful information, including links to temporary housing, hostels and other off-campus options. Applications and/or reservations would need to be sent/made as soon as possible to insure a space when you arrive. Prices vary as do application procedures. (To access the listings at the yellow “Students” link, UH username and password required.) East-West Center – Next to campus and has two housing facilities for students: Hale Manoa and Hale Kuahine. Both facilities are primarily reserved for graduate students formally affiliated with the East- West Center, but any students are welcome to apply. Space is limited, and priority will be given to students majoring in Asia-Pacific related studies.
cost_of_living: The University of Hawaii estimates that the monthly living expenses for international students are approximately $1,400-$2,000. This includes accommodation, meals, transportation, textbooks, and personal expenses. Please note that these are just estimates and actual expenses may vary depending on individual lifestyles and choices.

faculties_accepted: Foreign Languages and Literature, Interpreting and Translation
module_restrictions: There are no specific language requirements for studying at the University of Bologna. However, before coming to Bologna students are strongly advised to have at least basic knowledge of Italian (level A2) for daily conversation, and, in order to be able to study and make the most of the lessons, students are strongly advised to have level B1.
visa_info: Non-EU citizen students going to UNIBO for more than 90 days will need to apply for a Visa for study purposes to enter Italy. An invitation letter from UNIBO will be sent to students for applying the Visa from the Italian Embassy or Consulate in the home country. The visa issuing procedure can take several months therefore students are suggested to apply early. Students should request the health insurance to be stamped by the Embassy/Consulate when applying for the visa such that it can be used for application of residency Permit, which is to be done upon arrival in Italy. When arrive in Italy, students must also apply for a Residence Permit. This is a compulsory procedure for all non-EU citizens wishing to stay in Italy for more than 90 days.
accommodations_info: Bologna welcomes a large number of students and finding accommodation can be difficult, especially in September at the beginning of the academic year. Start looking for accommodation well in advance. It is advisable to book an accommodation before arriving in Bologna.
cost_of_living:
The estimated monthly living expenses in Bologna are as follows:

- Accommodation: €500 + utilities
- Food: €240
- Transport: €40
- Others (Entertainment, clothes): €140

The monthly estimate is between €800-1000.

module_restrictions: Courses offered by the Faculty of Dentistry and Li Ka Shing Faculty of Medicine are not open to exchange students. BSc (Exercise and Health) Programme and most Final year project courses provided by all faculties are also excluded. Courses offered by the Faculty of Business and Economics (FBE) are highly competitive and course enrollment is not guaranteed.
visa_info: All non-local students are required to obtain a student visa to study in HKSAR. Please complete the online visa application by the deadline and send hard copies of application documents to the designated visa office. Processing the visa application will take at least 10 weeks and the visa application fee is non-refundable. For more information on visa application procedures, please refer to https://www.studentvisa.hku.hk/
accommodations_info: On-campus accommodation for exchange students is on a first-come-first-served basis and not guaranteed. Students can apply for accommodation before receiving the Notice of Admission through CEDARS Accommodation Office. Most rooms are double rooms, but limited single rooms are available at St. John's College, Ricci Hall, and HKU Residential Colleges. Some halls have compulsory meal plans, while others do not. For more information, please refer to https://www.cedars.hku.hk/index.php?route=accommodation/accommodation and http://www.cedars.hku.hk/sections/accommodation.php

Faculty of Economical Science and Business Management
module_restrictions: Students must apply for courses they wish to study through the learning agreement. First year courses are not open to exchange students. Some of the courses are extremely popular (economics, philosophy), places will be assigned in order of application. Students must enroll a minimum of 2 courses worth 6 ECTS each for a semester stay. If they would like to read more than 2 courses, at least 51% of the courses selected must belong to one faculty/school where you have been accepted (for example, 3 courses from 3 different schools will not be accepted, 2 courses must belong to one school, and the 3rd course can be taken at a different school).
visa_info: Students studying in Spain for longer than 3 months are required to obtain a student visa before travelling to Spain. Contact your local embassy for information. All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university. Some visa application process could take up to 2 months to process. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country. For more information about visa, please refer to: https://www.uam.es/uam/en/internacional/visado-nie-tie http://www.exteriores.gob.es/Embajadas/SINGAPUR/en/Embajada/ServiciosConsulares/Pages/Visas.aspx
accommodations_info:
UAM does not provide accommodation for our incoming students. However, we could help you with some information about lodging in Madrid: In the Campus of Cantoblanco you have the option of staying at Residencia Universitaria Erasmo (managed privately). The UAM also offers housing with the Colegio Mayor Juan Luis Vives, which is located in Plaza de Castilla, which allows an easy commute to the campus. For more information on Accommodation, please refer to https://www.uam.es/uam/en/internacional/alojamiento

ii) Private Accommodation
The UAM has collaboration agreement with some housing companies: ALUNI and UNIPLACES. Off campus, there are other non-university residences such as: Residencia de estudiantes Ciudad Escolar (mixed), Masterhome residencia, and www.nexoresidencias.com. Finally, you always have the option to rent an accommodation by visiting the sites that manage the housing market in Madrid: http://www.fotocasa.es/ and http://www.segundamano.es/

module_restrictions: The following departments do not accept exchange students: School for Continuing Studies (Liberal Studies), School of Medicine, School of Law, Masters of Business Administration (MBA), Master of Science in Foreign Service (MSFS), Communication, Culture, & Technology (CCT), Public Policy (PBPO), and National Security Studies (NSST).
visa_info: All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they receive the official offer letter/email from their host university. Some visa application processes can take up to 2 months to process. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country. Once you are admitted to the university, Undergraduate Admissions will send you a Certificate of Eligibility (Form DS-2019). This document, together with your notification of admission, the financial guarantee and your passport, is used to obtain a J-1 visa at a U.S. consulate nearest to you. To apply for a visa in your home country, you must apply early and expect delays. Consult individual embassy Web sites for periodic updates on country-specific visa processing.
accommodations_info: Georgetown is unable to guarantee housing for all exchange students as spaces are limited. However, Georgetown will try to award on-campus housing to as many students as possible, and the Office of Global Education will assist students with their housing search if on-campus housing is not available.
cost_of_living: The estimated monthly living expenses can be found at https://finaid.georgetown.edu/undergrad/aid-for-undergrads/# (tuition fees waived for exchange students).

faculties_accepted: Faculty of Engineering & Design (CDE or FoE)
module_restrictions: Postgraduate modules are not open to undergraduate exchange students
visa_info: UK Visa and Immigration updates their immigration policy regularly. It is the student’s responsibility to check on the requirements via their website before they leave for the exchange.
accommodations_info: Exchange students can choose between two city centre locations: Pulteney Court and Thornbank Gardens. You can check accommodation prices for exchange students here. For more information on housing, please refer here.
cost_of_living:
The estimated living expenses per semester are as follows:

- Accommodation: £550 - £700 per month in our student residences
- Food: £250
- Transport: £200/semester (bus from city center to University)
- Insurance: [link to healthcare in the UK as an international student]
- Others (Entertainment, clothes, mobile phone, utilities, books etc.): £300

module_restrictions: Most courses at GW are open to exchange students who meet the prerequisite requirements. Law, nursing, medicine, interior design, architecture and Semester in Washington Program (denoted as PGMT) courses are restricted. In addition, exchange students may not enrol in graduate level courses (labelled 4999 and above).
visa_info: After you have submitted the documentation mentioned in the application section above, the GW Office for Study Abroad’s Exchange Team will do a preliminary application scan for completeness. The Exchange Team will then forward your file on to the International Services Office which will process your documentation to create a DS-2019 (a Visa request document). You will be guided through the visa application with help from the ISO and the GW Exchange Team. As part of the exchange application process, students will be asked to submit a Financial Certificate Form as well as proof of funds in order to receive a DS-2019. Please note that applications from prospective students requiring a DS-2019 from GW are not considered complete without these materials. Please note that a DS-2019 can only be issued once sufficient funding is documented for you and any accompanying dependents, whether that funding comes from you, a third party, GW, or a combination of these. Funds must be certified in U.S. currency and, if your documents are in a language other than English, an original, certified English translation must be provided. Financial documents should be as current as possible and may not be more than 12 months old at the time your GW studies will begin. Unless you are offered a University assistantship at the time of admission, you should not plan to work in the U.S. to support your studies.
accommodations_info: Campus housing is the most convenient place for students to reside while studying at GW. Over 7,000 students live on campus and enjoy the proximity to the academic buildings, library, dining hall, basketball stadium, and Office for Study Abroad. Exchange students are guaranteed housing on campus and are housed in apartment style dorms (including a kitchen) with two or more suitemates. Students typically only share an immediate bedroom and bathroom with one other person. In the past, exchange students have lived in 1959 E Street, City Hall, Ivory Tower, and Amsterdam Hall. The housing team works hard to try and ensure that exchange students are mixed in with American students and exchange students from countries other than your own.
cost_of_living: The estimated monthly living expenses at The George Washington University vary depending on personal spending habits. However, some general costs include housing (on-campus or off-campus), groceries, transportation, personal expenses, and health insurance. More information can be found at https://studyabroad.gwu.edu/costs-incoming-exchange

visa_info: Exchange students who study for one semester only (less than 6 months) are not required to apply for a study permit. However, depending on your country of citizenship, you may have to apply for an eTA OR a visitor visa. For more information on visa applications, please refer to https://www.cic.gc.ca/english/visit/visas.asp.
accommodations_info: All international exchange students are enrolled automatically in iMED upon registration in courses: https://global.ubc.ca/go-global/coming-ubc-study-abroad/coming-ubc-exchange/budgeting-exchange. It is recommended that you purchase a comprehensive travel insurance for the full duration of your stay abroad, including your personal travel within/outside Canada. Please review the insurance coverages to ensure that they meet your needs. Students can purchase additional health and/or travel insurance from their preferred agent.
cost_of_living: There is no specific information about the cost of living provided in the PDF.

module_restrictions: Students should select courses within a faculty per semester. In principle, undergraduate exchange students can only select undergraduate courses and postgraduate exchange students can only select postgraduate courses. Exchange students should get approval from both colleges for cross college course selection.
visa_info: Exchange students in China are required to apply for student visa (X2 visa for those intending to study in China for a period of no more than 180 days and X1 visa for those intending to study in China for a period of more than 180 days). You will receive the admission letter and visa application form (JW202) once you are accepted by the host university for the student exchange programme. Exchange students are required to apply for the student visa in person at the China Visa Application Service Centre in Singapore with the relevant documents before the start of the academic semester. China Visa Application Service Centre in Singapore: https://www.visaforchina.cn/SGP2_EN/index.shtml
accommodations_info: Siming Campus: The overseas student apartment buildings on the Siming Campus are set in picturesque surroundings and enjoy a view of the sea and fresh air. The dorms are equipped with a range of amenities. Newly enrolled students on Siming campus should apply online for on-campus accommodation. Detail information about on-campus accommodation application will be available in the Enrolment Instruction for New Students. Off-Siming Campus accommodation: Living off campus provides greater opportunities for international students to interact with the locals and to learn about the local community and culture. Students can choose to rent off-campus apartments and the monthly rental is around RMB 2,500 per room. When living off-campus, international students will enjoy a quiet learning environment.
cost_of_living: The cost of living in Xiamen University varies depending on the accommodation chosen. For on-campus accommodation, the monthly cost ranges from $200 to $400. Off-campus apartments can be rented for around RMB 2,500 per room. In addition, students should budget for meals, transportation, study materials, and personal expenses, which would amount to approximately $300 to $500 per month.

module_restrictions: Graduate courses are offered to senior year undergraduate students who have completed at least two and a half years of study at their undergraduate study.
visa_info: Upon acceptance, Tokyo Tech will apply for a Certificate of Eligibility on your behalf with the Japanese Ministry of Justice, and send it to you when issued. The certificate is required for you to apply for a study visa. Exchange students must obtain a “College Student” visa for the duration of their study in Japan. Please visit the Japan Embassy website for the required supporting documents for your visa application. All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university. This is to ensure that you can obtain your visa in time before the start of your exchange term. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country.
accommodations_info: Accommodation options for YSEP students: - Shofu Ryugakusei Kaikan (about 15 minutes’ walk from Aobadai station in Kanagawa prefecture) - Umegaoka Ryugakusei Kaikan (about 20 minutes’ walk from Fujigaoka station in Kanagawa prefecture) - Students will be assigned twin rooms with other YSEP students - Accommodation is not guarantee due to limited dormitory rooms - Successful applicants will be provided with information on housing about one or one and a half month before enrolment. Tokyo Tech will try to arrange a dormitory for ACAP students, subject to availability as the dormitory is limited.

The monthly estimate ranges from JP¥85,000 to JP¥153,000.

module_restrictions: Exchange students are not eligible to pursue the following fields of study: Medicine, Dentistry, Liberal Arts and Sciences (from University College Freiburg), Psychology, Pharmacy, and Molecular Medicine. visa_info: EU citizens and citizens from Australia, Canada, Honduras, Iceland, Israel, Japan, Korea, Liechtenstein, Monaco, New Zealand, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland, and the United States do not need a visa to enter Germany. Students from all other countries must apply for a visa for study purposes via the German diplomatic representation in their home country. All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university.
accommodations_info: The International Office will provide accommodation in a student dormitory to all University of Freiburg Global Exchange students upon application. Student dormitories with single apartments or single rooms in shared apartments are available. They are 5-15 minutes by tram or bus, 5-20 minutes by bicycle, 10-40 minutes on foot from the university, depending on dorm location. Meals are not included. Please note that rooms in the student dormitory are only rented for the whole semester (Summer semester: 1st April till 30th September). Students who have a contract that ends in September are expected to pay for the rental until September even if they are returning back to NUS by early August. There will be no refund of the rental if you leave the student accommodation earlier. A deposit of €400 to €500 for the dormitory will be refunded at the end of the contract.
cost_of_living: The estimated monthly living expenses include accommodation (€250 - €400), food (€200), insurance (€90), and other expenses like entertainment and clothes (€260 - €320). The monthly estimate ranges from €800 - €1,010. Exchange students need to present a statement of financial support proving that they have at least €735 to live on for each month of their stay in order to receive a residence permit.

Students will be informed about housing possibilities within 8 weeks of the application deadline. KIT reserves rooms for students from partner universities in their students’ residences if possible. These furnished single rooms cost about €355 and have a set lease period from March to August. No other moving in/out date is possible. A contract ending in August or September requires payment until August or September with no refund if the student leaves earlier.

university_name: ETH Zurich (Swiss Federal Institute of Technology)
faculties_accepted: Department of Agriculture and Food Sciences
Department of Civil, Environmental and Geomatic Engineering
Department of Biosystems Science and Engineering
Department of Chemistry and Applied Biosciences
Department of Information Technology and Electrical Engineering
Department of Mechanical and Process Engineering
module_restrictions: Exchange students will be enrolled in one department as non-degree students, but they may pick and choose courses from different curricula, departments, and years. As a general rule, 2 thirds of the courses have to be taken in the department of enrolment. Exchange students are expected to acquire a minimum of 20 ECTS (not including the language course/s). The full workload for regular ETH students is 30 ECTS per semester. Study plans and selected courses are subject to approval by the departmental exchange coordinator of the department of enrolment at ETH Zurich. Courses ending with –AAL are not open to exchange students. Modules from the department of Management, Technology and Economics (D-MTEC) are not open to NUS exchange students. Biology (D-BIOL): For block courses, there is an internal registration procedure and places are limited. Note that block courses are very difficult to combine with courses from other study programmes, they are intended only for combination with the Departments’ concept courses. More information can be found on the website of D-BIOL. Computer Science (D-INFK): Especially the Department of Computer Science has recently defined their admission criteria in a more specific but also somewhat more restrictive manner. Their respective conditions for the admission of exchange students can be found on their website. Humanities, Social and Political Sciences: No enrolment is possible in the department of Humanities, Social and Political Sciences (D-GESS), incoming students may only take individual courses (max. 1/3 of all courses/ECTS) as electives. Management, Technology and Economics: Students applying to the department of management, technology, and economics (D-MTEC) must have completed their Bachelor's degree in the field of mechanical engineering, electrical engineering, information technology, natural sciences, or any other equivalent field of study. In order to be accepted in the department of Mathematics (D-MATH) at ETH Zurich, a student must be enrolled for a degree in mathematics in their home university. Please note that courses offered by the department of Mechanical and Process Engineering (D-MAVT) in the category Engineering Tools, Laboratory Practice, Focus Project, and Workshop Floor are not allowed for incoming mobility students. Enrollment is not possible in the department of Humanities, Social and Political Sciences (D-GESS) and students can only take the department’s courses as electives (max. 1/3 of courses). Please note that the department of Biosystems Science and Engineering (D-BSSE) is located in Basel, a city approximately 100 km away from Zurich, therefore the services of the Student Exchange Office might be slightly limited.
visa_info: All visa applications are processed by ETH Zurich. Students will be informed after their acceptance about the further procedures. Everyone staying for more than 90 days (irrespective of whether they required a visa or not) is required to obtain a residence permit. Instructions on how to apply for it will be provided to students when they register in person at our helpdesk. Students need to follow the instructions and apply for their residence permit within 14 days after arrival. Important: The exact duration of the residence permit is calculated from the day of entrance to Switzerland and according to the duration of studies confirmed by ETH Zurich in the official confirmation of acceptance. Students should therefore never enter Switzerland before the start date stated on their official confirmation of acceptance. Otherwise, they risk their residence permit expiring before the last day of their planned mobility stay and not being able to write their final exams or finish their project/thesis work. In such case, they would have to apply for an extension of their residence permit at a charge. This applies to all non-EU/EFTA nationals, with and without a visa requirement, even if the visa authorization or the issued visa theoretically allows an earlier entry to Switzerland! Visa and residence permit fees usually amount to approx. CHF 400.
accommodations_info: Student accommodation in Zurich is available through the Foundation for Student Housing. The Housing Office of the University and ETH Zurich brokers accommodation on the private market. ETH Zurich has limited reserved housing for international students. Single rooms are common. You find offers with or without cooking facility, apartment sharing, cleaning and washing service, and bedding. All student accommodation in the city and the suburbs is located no further than 30 minutes from campus by using public transportation. Housing is not guaranteed, but so far ETH has usually been able to find accommodation for all overseas exchange students who registered with ETH’s Housing Office within the set deadlines. After acceptance, students will receive information on registering for accommodation by email. They should read this information carefully and apply online within the set deadlines. Please note: Students coming for research projects can only apply for housing if they are staying for the regular semester dates. Students older than 28 years cannot be accommodated in our student housing. Housing for students coming in the autumn semester is only available until 31 January and therefore not for the entire duration of the session examinations. Students staying for the full duration of the session examinations and having examinations in February would need to find alternative housing on their own for those 2-3 weeks. We may only be able to offer some partial financial support (subject to availability), yet this may not cover the full additional costs. Should a student initially only apply for one semester of exchange and then later on wish to extend for another semester, we may not be able to provide accommodation, i.e. the student may need to find something on his or her own.
cost_of_living:
Estimated Monthly Living Expenses:

- Food: CHF 500
- Transport: CHF 60 - CHF 90
- Others (Entertainment, clothes): CHF 425

Students should budget approximately CHF 1,750 per month (requirement of migration authorities).

faculties_accepted: Faculty of Social Sciences (excluding School of Business)
module_restrictions: Please note that for most courses there are special eligibility requirements which are determined by the departments. Students may choose any course in the study area named in the agreement, provided that they meet the prerequisites specified for each course. It is important that the home university approves the courses students plan to take at Stockholm University. Students should choose courses together with the department at the home university and the department at Stockholm University.
visa_info:
Students from outside the EU/EEA must apply for a residence permit at the Swedish Embassy/Consulate in their country of residence, directly after receiving the headed admissions letter from Stockholm University. Applications for a residence permit can under no circumstances be submitted after entering Sweden. Students are strongly advised to apply as soon as they receive their Letter of Acceptance, since it may take up to three months to get the documentation finalised. The following documents are required:

- A copy of a valid passport or ID-card
- Letter of admission from Stockholm University stating the duration of studies
- Proof that you can support yourself during your stay in Sweden (i.e. a bank statement in your name); the applicable minimum amount per month of stay is stipulated at the Swedish Migration Board website
- A valid health insurance, if the duration of the programme is one year or less.
accommodations_info: As a special service Stockholm University tries to assist students from partner universities with accommodation. Stockholm University does not own any student dormitories and does not normally organise accommodation for students. A special exception is made for exchange students from universities with which Stockholm University has a signed co-operation agreement. The Housing Office at the International Exchange Unit manages a limited number of rooms in Stockholm. Unfortunately, due to the high demand and shortage of accommodation in Stockholm, it cannot guarantee accommodation for every exchange student. In order to be able to apply for housing you need to be an exchange student. Exchange students apply for accommodation on the general registration form or via the on-line application form for exchange students.
cost_of_living:

- Accommodation: SEK4,000
- Food: SEK2,000
- Transport: SEK600
- Telephone/Internet: SEK300
- Others (Entertainment, clothes): SEK1,100

The monthly estimate for living expenses is SEK8,000.

visa_info: All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they receive the official offer letter/email from their host university. The visa application process could take up to 2 months to process. Your exchange at the host university depends on clearance by the immigration of the host country. Please check if you need a visa here: https://www.irishimmigration.ie/wp- content/uploads/2021/07/Immigration-Service-Delivery-Visa-and-Non-Visa- Required-Countries.pdf All students who do NOT hold an EU passport must register with the Irish Naturalisation and Immigration Service (INIS) after arrival in Ireland. Further information on the requirements to register can be found on the INIS website: https://www.irishimmigration.ie/coming-to-study-in- ireland/before-and-after-you-arrive/what-do-i-need-to-do-after-arriving/. UCC’s information on visa and immigration can be found here: https://www.ucc.ie/en/international/studentinfohub/beforeyouarrive/visaandimmigration/

module_restrictions: Please note that modules from Faculty of Medicine and Faculty of Dentistry are not open to exchange students. Access to courses in Biosciences and Law is restricted.
visa_info: EU citizens and citizens from the following countries do not need a visa to enter Germany: Australia, Canada, Honduras, Iceland, Israel, Japan, Korea, Liechtenstein, Monaco, New Zealand, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland, and the United States. However, after entering Germany, you will have to apply for a residence permit at the local 'Auslaenderbehörde' (Immigration Office) if you are staying for more than three months. Students from all other countries must apply for a visa for study purposes via the German diplomatic representation in their home country. You must not under any circumstances travel to Germany on a tourist visa.
accommodations_info: Student residences at Heidelberg University are administered by the Studierendenwerk, an independent organization providing various services to the student population. Although the number of available rooms is quite limited, the Akademisches Auslandsamt cooperates with the Studierendenwerk to secure rooms in student residences for international exchange students coming to Heidelberg. In some of the dormitories, internet access is available but cannot be guaranteed. Further, the internet access in the dorms is usually cable-bound and only a few have wireless LAN access. Internet access is not available in some dormitories located in Heidelberg’s old town. Students who prefer to live in private accommodation can receive information about private rooms and apartments in the area through the accommodation service at the Akademische Auslandsamt. Please note that private sector rents are considerably higher than rents in student residences.
cost_of_living:
The estimated monthly living expenses in Heidelberg are as follows:

Accommodation (for a dorm room): €220 - €350
Food: €170 - €220
Insurance (with state health insurance provider): €91
Others (Entertainment, clothes, telecommunication): €65 - €200

Monthly Estimate: €746 - €861. In order to receive a residence permit, you need to present to the Ausländerbehörde (local foreigner’s registration office) a statement of financial support proving that you have at least €735 to live on for each month of your stay. This can either be a bank statement, a notarized parental letter, or a scholarship certificate.

This is to ensure that you can obtain your visa in time before the start of your exchange term. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country. For more information on visa applications, please refer to http://sup.bureau.tohoku.ac.jp/visa/index_en.html http://www.mofa.go.jp/j_info/visit/visa/index.html

module_restrictions: Exchange students may not take classes in Music, Law, or Education. Students who wish to take architecture, engineering, business or journalism at CU should already have a background in those subject areas before coming to University of Colorado Boulder. Business and Engineering courses are often over-subscribed.
visa_info: For visa information, please refer to the following CU Boulder webpage: https://www.colorado.edu/isss/student-resources/admittednew-students/visa-and-immigration
accommodations_info:
Here is some information to help you choose the housing for your exchange term(s) and, if university housing is your choice, to help you apply for this housing. If you are an international exchange student coming to CU Boulder on one of our official exchange programs, the following applies to you:

Exchange student housing choices:

- University housing in apartments: the Bear Creek apartments can be a very good choice for exchange students. Bear Creek is run by the university and offers many social activities in addition to housing. Accommodation is in self-catering, ensuite apartments for students who are beyond their first year of university study. You apply as an individual and will be matched with roommates(s). Although the normal contract is for 9 or 12 months, if you will only be here for a semester, Bear Creek will allow a contract for the semester only if space allows. You apply online. **Note that Bear Creek is not an option for exchange students for the 2021-2022 Academic Year.
- Off-campus housing: we strongly recommend that students who wish to live off-campus arrive to find housing 1 - 2 weeks earlier than the date on the immigration document.
- Advice on housing from former exchange students: a good source of information about housing in Boulder can come from former or current exchange students. Please reach out to NUS Global Relations Office if you would like to be connected with your seniors who have embarked on SEP to CU Boulder.
cost_of_living: For more information on the costs associated with attending CU Boulder, please refer to the following link. Please note exchange students will not be required to pay CU Boulder tuition fees: https://www.colorado.edu/financialaid/cost/example-aid
