visa_info: https://reciprocity.uceap.universityofcalifornia.edu/after-you-apply/visa-resources
accommodations_info: Apply for housing as soon as you receive instructions from UCEAP (usually by e-mail), even if you have not yet received final confirmation of your acceptance to the programme. For specific housing options at each UC campus and application instructions, please refer here: https://reciprocity.uceap.universityofcalifornia.edu/before-you-arrive/campus-specific-instructions. It may be difficult for students who would prefer non-UC housing in the community to finalise independent living (off-campus) arrangements before arrival. You should arrive at your host campus as early as possible (no more than 30 days prior to the programme start date on your visa document) to look for housing.
cost_of_living: The estimated monthly living expenses can be found here: https://reciprocity.uceap.universityofcalifornia.edu/plan-your-studies/budget

module_restrictions: All UAF Schools/Colleges accept exchange students except for the College of Rural and Community Development which has limited course options.
visa_info: All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they receive the official offer letter/email from their host university. Some visa application processes can take up to 2 months to process. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country. Once you are admitted to the university, Undergraduate Admissions will send you a Certificate of Eligibility (Form DS-2019). This document, together with your notification of admission, the financial guarantee and your passport, is used to obtain a J-1 visa at a U.S. consulate nearest to you. To apply for a visa in your home country, you must apply early and expect delays. Consult individual embassy Web sites for periodic updates on country-specific visa processing.
accommodations_info: All on-campus housing (except the Sustainable Village) requires the purchase of a meal plan. Cutler and Wickersham meal plan requirements offer more flexibility with the size of the meal plan, so if students plan on cooking their own meals, they should select one of those two options. Students may request a single room, but it is likely that they will have to share a room with a roommate because of the housing shortage on campus. Rates can be found here: http://www.uaf.edu/reslife/rates/. Please note that undergraduates under the age of 26 are not eligible to apply for the options listed under ‘Affordable Apartment Rates’.
cost_of_living: There are several mandatory student fees which are not included in a tuition waiver for exchange students. Students should be prepared to pay approximately USD $2,500 in mandatory fees each semester.

visa_info: EU citizens and citizens from the following countries do not need a visa to enter Germany: Australia, Canada, Honduras, Iceland, Israel, Japan, Korea, Liechtenstein, Monaco, New Zealand, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland and the United States. However, after entering Germany, you will have to apply for a residence permit at the local 'Auslaenderbehörde' (Immigration Office) if you are staying for more than three months. Students from all other countries must apply for a visa for study purposes via the German diplomatic representation in their home country. You must not under any circumstances travel to Germany on a tourist visa.
accommodations_info: Students will be housed in one of several student dorms, which are located in different areas of town. All dorms are easily accessible either by foot or by public transportation. All rooms are single rooms. Some are equipped with a kitchenette and a private bathroom while others have shared facilities. Rent is about €200-350 per month. Meals are not included. Students who have a contract that ends in August or September are expected to pay for the rental until August or September. There will be no refund of the rental if you leave the student accommodation earlier.

module_restrictions: Students are expected to take master level courses taught in English as most Bachelor level courses are taught in Swedish. Only students in 3rd year and above are able to participate in SEP to Chalmers University of Technology. 3rd year semester 2 students are preferred.  Architecture students must be in 4th year to participate in exchange to Chalmers. NUS students cannot attend courses from Chalmers Department of Technology Management and Economics which includes Industrial Engineering and Business courses.
visa_info:
Students from non EU/EEA countries need to apply for a residence permit for studies before entering Sweden. Further information and application forms regarding residence permit may be obtained from the Swedish Embassy or Consulate in the home country of the student, or from Migrationsverket (the Migration Board). Students are strongly advised to apply as soon as they receive their Letter of Acceptance, since it may take up to three months to get the documentation finalised. In order to apply for a residence permit for studies, students must:

- Have a valid passport
- Be admitted to full time studies
- Be able to support herself or himself for the planned study period (ie a bank statement in your name); the applicable minimum amount per month of stay is stipulated at the Swedish Migration Board website
- Have a comprehensive health insurance that covers the whole period of stay in Sweden if admitted for less than a year

All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university.  Visa application process could take up to 3 months to process. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country.
accommodations_info: Gothenburg is a popular city to study in and there is a very high demand for student housing. Finding appropriate accommodation may be difficult, especially in the central parts of the city. Chalmers cannot guarantee accommodation for exchange students but will try best to provide accommodation to the incoming exchange students. Incoming exchange students from NUS will receive an email from Chalmers with instruction about how to apply for housing in Gothenburg.  Students are expected to search actively for housing, which means that you may have to put yourself in the queue systems for the housing agencies. It is important that you don't wait until the last minute, as soon as you receive your admissions letter you should start looking for accommodation. Chalmers has agreements with the housing agencies SGS Studentbostäder and Chalmers studentbostäder. Make sure to apply directly to each of these agencies.

Students are expected to obtain a J-1 Student Entry Visa. All residence halls have lounges, TVs and laundry facilities. All campus buildings are smoke-free and most halls have substance-free floors. International exchange students are required to live in one of the on-campus residential halls.

university_name: University of Michigan at Ann Arbor
module_restrictions: Exchange students cannot enroll in courses from the School of Dentistry, Law School, Medical School, or college of Pharmacy. Courses in Business and Engineering are not available, except by special arrangement. Exchange students are not eligible to enroll in courses through the Medical School, the School of Architecture and Urban Planning, Dentistry, Law, Medicine, Nursing, Pharmacy and Public Health. Students are not restricted but also not guaranteed enrollment in courses from the following Colleges: Art and Design, Business, Education, Engineering, Rackham, Information, Kinesiology, Music Theater and Dance, Natural Resources, Public Policy and Social Work. Courses from these faculties are usually held for degree-seeking students enrolled in the respective faculties and rarely open for students outside their field. Incoming students are able to apply for courses offered through the College of Literature, Science and Arts, though again there are no guarantees for particular courses.
visa_info: A visa is a document granting permission for entry and/or extended stay in a country. Visas are stamped or fastened into an applicant’s passport. You are responsible for obtaining the necessary visas and for all associated costs. In most cases, the process of obtaining a visa is smooth when the application is made well ahead of time and the destination country’s instructions are followed carefully. Requirements for student visas vary from programme to programme, country to country, consulate to consulate, and term to term. The type of visa you will need depends on your citizenship, type of experience (study only, internship, tourism, and so on), the country or countries you visit, and the duration of each stay. You may seek advice from a CGIS advisor or program sponsor, but obtaining the appropriate visa is your responsibility. Familiarize yourself with the host country visa requirements for citizens of your own home country. CGIS cannot obtain a visa for you nor does CGIS have control over consulates and the regulations they impose. Be aware that you need a passport before applying for a visa, that some countries have certain medical requirements, and that the application process can take up to 4 months. Begin investigating visa requirements immediately after being accepted into a program to provide enough time for the entire process. You might be required to go in person to your host country's consulate or embassy to apply, which might require travel to another city or state. If you are not US citizens but possess a Green Card (Permanent Residence) for the US, follow the visa instructions for the country that issued your official passport. Contact your host country's consulate immediately and follow their instructions. If you do not have a Green Card, inform the UM International Center that you are going abroad to ensure all conditions of your US student visa are met.
accommodations_info: Exchange students typically enjoy residence halls (dorms) because rooms are shared with another student (from all over the U.S. and world), meal plans can be purchased, and many activities are available. Residence Halls are a true part of the U.S. college experience. For more information please refer to the following link: https://housing.umich.edu/ Northwood Apartments: https://housing.umich.edu/residence-hall/northwood-iii/ On-campus apartments are located on north campus, which is about a 20-minute bus ride from central campus. For students seeking a quieter environment. Off-Campus Apartments/Shared Houses: https://housing.umich.edu/off-campus-housing/ We suggest finding off-campus housing through landlords registered at U-M. Prices and location can vary.
cost_of_living: The estimated monthly living expenses for exchange students at the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor can be found at this link: https://finaid.umich.edu/cost-of-attendance/ (Tuition is waived for exchange students).

visa_info: Exchange students must apply to New Zealand Immigration for a student visa and obtain the visa before entering New Zealand. Please note that it is NOT possible for exchange students to travel to New Zealand on a visitor's visa and apply for a student permit upon arrival in New Zealand, even if you are a citizen of a country with which New Zealand has a visa waiver agreement. It is imperative that all exchange students get their student visa BEFORE travelling to New Zealand, as you may be refused a student permit if you apply from within New Zealand. Students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university. This is to ensure that you can obtain your visa in time before the start of your exchange term. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country. For more information on visa applications, please refer to https://www.immigration.govt.nz/new-zealand-visas/options/study
cost_of_living: The cost of living in Victoria University of Wellington is estimated to be NZ$350 per semester. In addition, it is recommended that students purchase a comprehensive travel insurance for the full duration of their stay abroad, including personal travel within/outside New Zealand. Students can purchase additional health and/or travel insurance from their preferred agent.

module_restrictions:
Course Limitations For Exchange Students:
- School of Management (SOM) Graduate Courses: Only available to graduate students
- EMBA (Executive MBA) Courses (SOM courses with code 9XX): Not open to exchange students
- 3- MIF (Master of Finance courses with code MFIN) Courses: Only available to graduate students
- LFI (Leaders for Industry) Engineering Courses: Subject to the approval of the instructor
- LFI FMAN Courses: Only available to graduate students
- Courses taught in Turkish are not open for exchange students, except Turkish Basic I (TUR 101) & Turkish Basic II (TUR 102).
visa_info: All international students who need a visa should obtain their visa before coming to Turkey. Otherwise, you need to go back to your home country to obtain the visa if you need a student visa, as Student Visa is not given in Turkey. Students should apply for a visa at the nearest Turkish Embassy or Consulate in their home country at least 2 months before the academic semester begins. Residence Permit and Online Appointment: All exchange students must apply for a residence permit at İstanbul YABANCILAR ŞUBE MÜDÜRLÜĞÜ (VATAN) (Police Department for Foreigners - only one application branch) within a month after their arrival. Students cannot leave Turkey without having a residence permit. If this happens, you cannot come back to Turkey in the next 3 months.
accommodations_info: University Accommodation: Students must indicate their accommodation preferences in the application form if they want to stay on campus. The International Office at Sabanci will do its best to accommodate all students. However, capacity is limited, and therefore priority will be given to students who apply before the application deadline. Students are allowed to check in the dormitories one week before the beginning of the semester. Deposits are returned to students two days before they leave. Private Accommodation: If preferred, students may choose to live outside the university campus. In that case, you have the responsibility to find your own accommodation.

Per Semester Expenses: TRY7,624

module_restrictions:
1) NUPACE Special Undergraduate and Special Graduate Students majoring in Chemistry or Physics are generally not permitted to enrol in G30 courses with laboratory content.

2) Students wishing to apply for clerkships at the School of Medicine should carefully follow application notes and instructions on the NUPACE website.

Students must possess the prerequisite for the courses they are planning to read. If students plan to read courses taught in Japanese, they must possess N1/level 1 of the Japanese Language Proficiency Test (JLPT), or the equivalent.
visa_info:
Upon acceptance, Nagoya will apply for a Certificate of Eligibility on your behalf with the Japanese Ministry of Justice, and send it to you when issued. The certificate is required for you to apply for a study visa.

Exchange students must obtain a “College Student” visa for the duration of their study in Japan. Please visit the Japan Embassy website for the required supporting documents for your visa application.

All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university. This is to ensure that you can obtain your visa in time before the start of your exchange term. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country.
accommodations_info: All successful applicants are housed in single rooms in student dormitories, located either on-campus or close to the university. Approximately JP¥25,000 - JP¥45,000 per month, including utilities. NUPACE will apply for housing on the students’ behalf.
cost_of_living:
The estimated monthly living expenses are as follows:

- Accommodation: JP¥25,000 - JP¥45,000
- Food: JP¥20,000 - JP¥30,000
- Insurance: JP¥2,000
- Others (Entertainment, clothes): JP¥30,000

The monthly estimate ranges from JP¥77,000 - JP¥107,000. For more details, please refer to http://nupace.iee.nagoya-u.ac.jp/en/life/financial.html.

module_restrictions: Honours courses (third year classes) have limited places. Some subject areas and certain studio-based classes like Architecture, Landscape Architecture, and Art and Design are not available for exchange students. Please refer to the academic guide provided by The University of Edinburgh College of Humanities and Social Science for more information.
visa_info: UK Visa and Immigration updates their immigration policy regularly, so it is the student’s responsibility to check the requirements via their website before leaving for the exchange. Singapore citizens or citizens of other countries on the UK non-visa nationals list who are studying for less than 6 months can request entry to the UK as a Standard Visitor upon arrival. Students from other countries or those studying for a full-year exchange need a Student Visa for a full-year exchange in Edinburgh. Students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after receiving the official offer letter/email from their host university.
accommodations_info: Students must have accepted an unconditional offer to study at The University of Edinburgh before they can apply for accommodation. Exchange students are guaranteed accommodation if their application is submitted on time, but preferred room type cannot be guaranteed. Private accommodation is available in the Private Sector, but students need to be cautious of various scams operating in the Private Sector.
cost_of_living: The University of Edinburgh provides a detailed breakdown of living costs, which can be found at http://www.ed.ac.uk/studying/international/finance/cost-of-living. Students are advised to refer to this information for estimated monthly living expenses.

module_restrictions: Postgraduate modules are not open to undergraduate exchange students. Please see here for guidance on choosing modules: https://www.york.ac.uk/study/international/applying/visiting-students/courses/guidance-on-choosing-modules/
visa_info: UK Visa and Immigration updates their immigration policy regularly. It is the student’s responsibility to check on the requirements via their website before they leave for the exchange. For latest information on border control please see: https://www.gov.uk/uk-border-control
accommodations_info: As a visiting student, you are guaranteed accommodation if you have applied for your course place with Centre for Global Programmes by their stipulated deadlines. You can either live in an en-suite single bedroom or in a room with a wash basin and share a common bathroom. You can cook in a shared kitchen or eat in the dining rooms or snack-bars on campus. At each of the six colleges, there are common rooms, a bar, a television room, laundry, telephone facilities and a reception service. More information is available at http://www.york.ac.uk/about/departments/support-and-admin/accommodation/
cost_of_living: The estimated monthly living expenses can be found at https://www.york.ac.uk/students/housing-and-money/financial-support/budgeting/budgets/.

university_name: Institut National des Sciences Appliquées de Lyon (INSA Lyon)
module_restrictions: Energetics & Environmental Engineering (GEN) and Industrial Engineering (GI) accept full year exchange students or semester 1/autumn semester exchange students. Students have to choose at least 80 % of their courses in one single department (main department), but are allowed to pick up 20% of courses from other departments, should schedules permit.
visa_info: Long-Stay visas are necessary for stays exceeding 3 months. Upon arrival in France, students are required to register with the French Immigration and Integration Office (OFII) for a residence permit. Please visit the websites of French embassies and consulates in your country. All students who wish to study in France must follow the Campus France procedure on Etudes en France online platform before applying for a visa. Students can apply up to 3 months prior to the departure. During the peak period (from April to August), students are invited to apply as soon as they can, to avoid any delays, since it can take up to 2 weeks to get an appointment. All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university.
accommodations_info: INSA Lyon provides accommodation on-campus for all exchange students: 360 to 550 €. A total of eleven Halls, divided into two categories, are available at INSA Lyon. The first category is referred to as traditional halls of residence, with shared rooms for two students. The second category of Halls is called new residences, where larger flats which offer more comfort are available for students. All rooms are furnished (bed, desk, chair, wardrobe or cupboard) and are equipped with a kitchenette (refrigerator and hotplate).
cost_of_living: INSA Lyon is offering up to two scholarships (€3400 + €1100 for airfare per student) for NUS students on SEP to INSA Lyon (a minimum of 4 months is applicable) through the ERASMUS+ International credits mobility scheme. Scholarships are available for SEP in AY17/18. For more information about the cost of living, please refer to https://www.insa-lyon.fr/en/node/112. Breakdown of Costs: Accommodation: €305 - €525, Food: €230, Transport: €30, Insurance: €40, Others (Entertainment, clothes): €150, Monthly Estimate: €755 - €975.

visa_info:
Exchange students in China are required to apply for student visa (X2 visa
for those intending to study in China for a period of no more than 180 days
and X1 visa for those intending to study in China for a period of more than
180 days).
You will receive the admission letter and visa application form (JW202)
once you are accepted by the host university for the student exchange
programme.  Exchange students are required to apply for the student visa
in person at the China Visa Application Service Centre in Singapore with
the relevant documents before the start of the academic semester.
China Visa Application Service Centre in Singapore:
https://www.visaforchina.cn/SGP2_EN/index.shtml
https://www.visaforchina.cn/#/guideNav/Guidance?visacenterCode=SGP
2&request_locale=en_US&site_alias=SGP2_EN
Visa information at Fudan University:

accommodations_info:
Exchange students are housed at the International Students Dormitory
located northwest of the Fudan campus. There are single and double
rooms available. There is a 24-hour reception desk available at the lobby,
with a mini-supermarket and meeting place. The gymnasium and
students’ dining halls are nearby. Students who are staying for an entire
academic year are eligible for accommodation on campus during semester
breaks. Accommodation fees will be pro-rated.
On-campus accommodation is very limited and on first come first served
policy, students are reminded to check the booking period at the
following website and apply for accommodation early.
https://ogp.fudan.edu.cn/16089/list.htm
https://iso.fudan.edu.cn/isoenglish/16212/list.htm

If on-campus accommodation is not available, students are advised to try
the following resources as soon as possible:
1. Tonghe International Student village
Add: Wuong Road Lane 28 (off campus, across the road to Foreign
  Students Dormitory)
 Telephone number: +86-21-65105187
 Price Reference: A room in a 3-room apartment is 70/80/90 RMB/day.
2. Hanting Hotels and Inns
Add: Songhuajiang Road 2628 (off campus, close to undergraduate
 living area)
 Telephone number: +86-21-61434888
 Price Reference: 140-180 RMB/day for king-size or double-bed room
For more information, please refer to
http://www.fao.fudan.edu.cn/32/d7/c16089a13015/page.htm
cost_of_living:
The cost of living in China varies depending on the city and lifestyle.

Generally, accommodation costs range from RMB 2,000 to RMB 5,000 per month for a single person.

Transportation expenses can be around RMB 200 to RMB 500 per month, depending on the mode of transportation used.

Meals can cost around RMB 1,500 to RMB 3,000 per month, depending on individual eating habits.

Other expenses, such as entertainment, books, and personal items, can add up to RMB 500 to RMB 1,000 per month.

Overall, the estimated total cost of living in China for a semester is approximately RMB 10,000 to RMB 20,000.

Faculty of Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics
module_restrictions: Postgraduate modules are not opened to undergraduate exchange students. NUS students can apply to most academic fields at TCD. There are, however, certain restrictions set out in TCD’s study abroad module directory that are not open to exchange students or are only open to Semester 2 or full-year exchange students. NUS students are not permitted to take Dentistry, Medicine and Business modules.
visa_info: All students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they receive the official offer letter/email from their host university. The visa application process could take up to 2 months to process. Your exchange at the host university depends on clearance by the immigration of the host country. Please check if you need a visa here: https://www.irishimmigration.ie/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/Immigration-Service-Delivery-Visa-and-Non-Visa-Required-Countries.pdf All students who do NOT hold an EU passport must register with the Irish Naturalisation and Immigration Service (INIS) after arrival in Ireland. Further information on the requirements to register can be found on the INIS website: https://www.irishimmigration.ie/coming-to-study-in-ireland/before-and-after-you-arrive/what-do-i-need-to-do-after-arriving/. Trinity’s Immigration FAQs for Students: https://www.tcd.ie/students/supports-services/international-students.php
accommodations_info: Accommodation on-campus is extremely limited and not guaranteed. Incoming students are mainly accommodated in College residences at Trinity Hall, Binary Hub and Kavanagh Court. Non-EU students can apply as soon as they have confirmed acceptance of an offer of a place in Trinity College and have received their TCD ID number. Private Accommodation: If you do not secure university housing, or wish to find your own accommodation, TCD’s Accommodation Advisory Service helps students to find accommodation by providing them with advice and access to house-hunting resources. Students are advised to arrive in Dublin at least 2-3 weeks before the teaching begins in order to secure suitable and affordable accommodation.
cost_of_living:
Estimated Monthly Living Expenses
Accommodation: €1000 approx.
Food: approx. €200 a month
Transport: depending on location, approx. €120 a month
Insurance: can range in price from €200 – €1,800 annually
Others (Entertainment, clothes, mobile phone, utilities, books etc.): €75-100 a month

module_restrictions: Postgraduate modules are not opened to undergraduate exchange students. Most of the courses in the faculty level programs are open to exchange students, pending availability. Participation in some courses requires approval from the department in which the student wishes to study.
visa_info: All students must obtain a MULTIPLE ENTRY A/2 STUDENT VISA prior to their arrival to Israel through the closest Israeli Embassy or Consulate. Students will be required to present their acceptance letter from the Rothberg International School to the Israeli Embassy or Consulate as part of their visa application. This visa is issued for the duration of study. Students in one-year programs or longer are advised to obtain the visa as close to their date of departure as possible, since a visa is only issued for a maximum of 12 months. The student’s passport must be valid for the full period of the visa. Students who arrive to Israel without an A/2 student visa may be required by the Israeli authorities to leave the country in order to obtain the correct visa.
accommodations_info: Housing is available at Technion but is not guaranteed. Incoming students will have the option to live in on-campus housing. On-campus housing on the main Technion campus (science and technology complex) consists of 6-person apartments; in each apartment, there are 3 bedrooms for 2 roommates each. These units are designed with a shared kitchen and bathroom. Students receive on-campus accommodations based on the program they are in. Bedrooms are equipped with a bed, a closet, and a desk. Linens are not provided. Kitchens come with a gas or electric burner and refrigerator. Microwaves, stoves, and kitchenware are not provided. All apartments have wireless internet. Electricity and internet expenses are paid for separately. There are laundromats equipped with washers and dryers in every dorm village. All dorm rooms are non-smoking; each building has a terrace where smoking is permitted. Private accommodation options are available in locations close to the Technion campus.
cost_of_living: While costs may vary according to your spending habits, it is generally recommended by Technion’s International Office to budget USD$500–$600 per month for food, entertainment, transportation, telephone, and other expenses. On-campus housing rates for visiting students are around USD $400 per month (depending on the dorm). Electricity, phone, and internet expenses are paid separately.

module_restrictions: Business courses are restricted for exchange students and some are reserved for degree-seeking students. Only general business courses may be available. Architecture, art, digital arts, music, and product design have additional admission requirements and may have some course restrictions.
visa_info: Exchange students at the University of Oregon will need to apply for a J-1 student visa to study in the US. Once students are admitted, a DS-2019 is issued by the UO based on the student’s admission to the University of Oregon and evidence of financial support. The DS-2019 is required to apply for a J-1 visa and is a required document for entry to the U.S. Students must keep their DS-2019 with their passport. The DS-2019 is sent with the student’s official letter of admission. Students may enter the U.S. up to 30 days before the DS-2019 program start date; not earlier! Students should carry their passport and visa, DS-2019, and letter of admission. Admission to the U.S. should be a smooth experience if everything is prepared in advance.
accommodations_info:
During ISO (International Student Orientation): If you need housing before ISO begins you can stay with a host family or find a hotel. If you plan to live on-campus, you can apply for early move-in. Please note you can request early arrival when your housing assignment is emailed around August.
How to apply for early move-in:
1. Receive your room assignment.
2. Log on to the Housing Portal and sign up for early arrival.
3. There will be a fee per day that you arrive early. Please note this fee depends on the room you are assigned to.
4. Please inform exchange@uoregon.edu that you plan to arrive early so we can notify the Housing Department.
Please contact the Housing Department if you have additional questions. Phone: +1 541 346 4277 Email: housing@uoregon.edu
Host Family Information: Limited spaces are available to stay with a local family for a few days (temporary) before moving into your residence hall or apartment (it’s free). Apply here. On-Campus Housing: Guide | Off-Campus Housing: Guide
cost_of_living: The estimated monthly living expenses for exchange students at the University of Oregon can be found on their website.

module_restrictions: Enrolment in the Biochemistry, Bioinformatics and Biology is subject to availability of lab classes and to prior approval by the institute/department. Medicine and Veterinary Medicine are NOT open to exchange students. Restrictions apply in Pharmacy, Law and Economics and Business Administration. All master’s programmes (other than Modern German Literature, Philosophy and Political Science) are restricted and need prior approval by the institute/ department.
visa_info: EU citizens and citizens from the following countries do not need a visa to enter Germany: Australia, Canada, Honduras, Iceland, Israel, Japan, Korea, Liechtenstein, Monaco, New Zealand, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland and the United States. However, after entering Germany, you will have to apply for a residence permit at the local "Auslaenderbehörde" (Immigration Office) if you are staying for more than three months. Students from all other countries must apply for a visa for study purposes via the German diplomatic representation in their home country. You must not under any circumstances travel to Germany on a tourist visa.
accommodations_info: On-campus accommodation is not available. Further information about accommodation options will also be available to students via the Distributed Campus platform. Either students can organize their own private accommodation (such as student-shared apartments, so-called WG=Wohngemeinschaft) or use the university's accommodation service offered by the ERG GmbH. The accommodation service offers a variety of accommodation options, including dorms, shared flats and fully furnished single apartments. All housing options are available from the beginning of September/October or March/April onwards and cost about 300 – 850 € per month.

module_restrictions: Modules available to exchange students can be found in the guide provided.
visa_info: UK Visa and Immigration updates their immigration policy regularly. It is the student’s responsibility to check on the requirements via their website before they leave for the exchange. For latest information on border control please see: [https://www.gov.uk/uk-border-control](https://www.gov.uk/uk-border-control). Standard Visitor Visa for Semester Exchange: If you are a Singapore citizen or a citizen of another country on the UK non-visa nationals list, and if your course of studies is less than 6 months, you will request entry to the UK as a Standard Visitor when you arrive. Singapore citizens do not normally need to meet with a Border Force agent, and will be able to enter the UK through E-gates. The E-gates will automatically grant you permission to stay in the UK for up to 6 months. You will not receive a stamp on your passport thus it is important that you retain evidence of when you entered the UK. Hence, please keep your boarding pass or evidence of your flight itinerary. Please refer here for more details on the Standard Visitor Visa. Student Visa for Full-Year Exchange: You need a Student Visa for a full-year exchange in Liverpool. For more details on visa application, read the information available here.
accommodations_info: Exchange students for a semester are able to apply for a room in the Study Abroad Village, which is located in Tudor Close and Melville Grove Halls of Residence. These consist of self-catered, single study bedrooms with shared bathrooms and social spaces. All accommodation has access to a residential advisor, as well as student-led events and committees. All communal areas are cleaned every weekday. [https://www.liverpool.ac.uk/study-abroad/inbound/study-in-liverpool/accommodation/](https://www.liverpool.ac.uk/study-abroad/inbound/study-in-liverpool/accommodation/)

visa_info: Once you have purchased the Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC), your host university will issue an Electronic Confirmation of Enrolment (eCoE), which is required for your Australian Student Visa Application. All exchange students must obtain an Australian Non Award Student Visa (sub-class 500) before arriving in Australia. Students are advised to apply for the necessary visa immediately after they received the official offer letter/email from their host university. This is to ensure that you can obtain your visa in time before the start of your exchange term. Your exchange at the host university depends on the clearance by the immigration of the host country. For more information on visa applications, please refer to https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/student-500.
